TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On 7 October Senator Sherry resigned as Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and as a member of the opposition executive. I am pleased to announce that today Senator Peter Cook has been elected Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. Can I also say that for the moment Senator Cook will take on Senator Sherry's representational responsibilities in this chamber. I indicate to the Senate that I will be making a statement about final shadow ministerial representational responsibilities in the near future.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Robert Hill, in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. What is the government's rationale for the dismantling of the Department of Administrative Services?

—That is an in‐depth question. I take the opportunity to congratulate Senator Cook on his election to such high office. I regret the circumstances in which he has achieved it but nevertheless I wish him well. The government believes that the functions of the Department of Administrative Services can be better conducted under the authority of the Department of Finance. We think we can achieve the administrative load that was its task in the past in a more efficient way and deliver the responsibilities of government more effectively. Basically, it is just a reorganisation of the administration to achieve the best outcome.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. That is really an answer that goes to the objectives of why you have reorganised, not why you have done so and where you think the savings can be made. Minister, how do you account for the fact that the former secretary, one of the deputy secretaries, eight other senior DAS officers and about 400 other departmental employees have lost their jobs? Why have they lost their jobs?
—I have to say that I do not think that that is so. There may well be some rationalisation of staff as a result of this. I have not—
—Are you sure?

—I said there may be some rationalisation of staff as a result of this, Senator Faulkner. I would have thought you would understand that. I think Senator Cook would understand that it is the responsibility of government to deliver the most efficient and effective service through the most efficient and effective administrative structure. That is the objective of this government and that was the reason for the decision that was taken.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Minister, you would be aware that illegal fishing has been a problem in Australia's Antarctic waters, particularly around the remote Heard and McDonald islands. What action has the government taken to protect Australia's sovereignty in these areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has been aware of a number of fishing vessels allegedly operating illegally in Australia's Southern Ocean territory around Heard and McDonald islands. Madam President, you would be aware that other illegals have been caught in recent times, particularly by France in its territories. I understand that there have been similar experiences in the territories of the United Kingdom, New Zealand and South Africa. You will appreciate the potential consequence of this to the unique environmental assets of the region. This is a very logistically difficult region, being so far from any land. Nevertheless, the assets of the region are unique and require protection.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to say that the Howard government has in fact taken decisive action to protect our Southern Ocean interests. At the government's direction, the Australian Defence Force has successfully apprehended two foreign fishing vessels allegedly operating illegally in Australia's exclusive economic zone surrounding the Heard and McDonald islands. It has been, as I indicated, a major undertaking of the ADF. Heard and McDonald islands are 4,000 kilometres from Perth, located in one of the wildest and most remote parts of the globe. The frigate HMAS Anzac was deployed during the operation. I understand that the two apprehended vessels are registered in Belize and Panama. They are returning with HMAS Anzac to Fremantle and should arrive towards the end of this month. It is possible that the masters of both vessels can be charged under the Fisheries Management Act. The penalty for illegal foreign fishing can include fines of up to $250,000 and forfeiture of the vessel's gear and catch.

In addition to protecting Australia's sovereignty by stopping illegal fishing, it is, as I indicated, vitally important to protect the environmental values of the region. Without enforcement action in the Heard and McDonald islands EEZ, illegal fishing could effectively destroy the region's commercial fish stocks, including the Patagonian toothfish. This would, of course, have major consequences on the region's ecosystems.

I particularly want to commend the Minister for Defence, Mr McLachlan; Senator Parer, who is responsible for fisheries; and Senator Ian Macdonald, who took a lead in arguing the case for the government to expend these resources to protect our natural environment. It demonstrates the determination of this government to protect our environmental assets, even when the cost of doing so is very expensive. It demonstrates the determination of our government to comply with the CCAMLAR regulations and to ensure that exploiting natural assets such as fishing is done in an environmentally responsible way. We will not tolerate abuses that put such environmental assets at risk.

I refer the minister to the recent anti‐Semitic attacks launched by the Malaysian Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir. Does the government see itself as able to publicly repudiate and reject these attacks?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts.
—The doormat for short.

—Thank you; far from it. The Howard government gave commitments during the last election to support emerging artists, cultural activity in regional Australia and the principle of triennial funding. Will the minister outline how the government is fulfilling these commitments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there was an area of stark contrast between the government and the opposition it has to be in the area of funding for the arts. I am sure members of the community vividly recall the grotesqueries of the Keating regime when Mr Keating was promoting schemes which involved the provision of hundreds of thousands of dollars to artists who were not in need of any financial assistance, were not required to be accountable and, in many instances, simply had to be well known to the leader. We have not seen any disownment of that approach by the Labor Party. We all look forward to the release of their draft platform in the next few weeks when, perhaps, we will get a glimmer of an insight into whether they have any notion of what funding for the arts is all about.

BREAK.PARA: The government has already announced a $3 million emerging artists program which will be of tremendous benefit to artists who are struggling—and there are very many of them. It will assist artists in regional communities, particularly those who require exhibition spaces, those who want to exhibit their works in other areas, those who want to undertake mentorship schemes, those who want studio access, and those who want to participate in concert series. We will be developing our first release CD scheme. There will be a whole series of initiatives to assist emerging artists in areas such as theatre creativity, visual and craft artistry, the mentorship scheme, the emerging music artists concert series scheme, the emerging Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander artists initiative, the emerging choreographers initiative, and the new media emerging artists initiative.

Last week I announced grants totalling $3.8 million for touring programs for Visions of Australia, Playing Australia and Festivals Australia. These are schemes designed to make up for the years of neglect when people outside the metropolitan areas simply did not get a look‐in, because Labor was interested in the big end of town.
What has happened since the last election? Absolutely nothing.
Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht, I commiserate with you on missing out on the deputy leadership of your party. It was not a big challenge but, unfortunately, you were not quite up to it. We now have Mr McMullan with a whole raft of responsibilities with arts tagged on. Of course, we have heard nothing from him yet on these schemes, let alone any repudiation of the `Keatings'. Prior to that, we had Carmen Lawrence who hardly said boo on the subject. In today's Newspoll I noticed, in passing, that Simon Crean ranks on the same level as Carmen Lawrence in terms of popularity. He happens to be one point behind that other category of `someone else'. So that tells you how well the opposition are going. There certainly is no‐one who is showing the slightest interest in the area of the arts, and I think the arts community are entitled to unde rstand that they were well and truly duped and hoodwinked for very many years.

BREAK.PARA: We have been giving particular emphasis to regional arts, and our regional arts fund will be of particular benefit to people outside the metropolitan areas. We have also announced recently a $24 million funding package from the Australia Council, $12 million of which has been committed to providing triennial funding to 26 outstanding arts organisations for the first time. There is a great deal happening in the arts under this government. There is the arts infolink which caters for something like 1,300 arts organisations and which has had over 300,000 hits on its web site, almost 80 per cent of which were in Australia, which shows that there is tremendous interest out there.

The tragedy is that only one side of politics is interested in the arts, and we will continue to ensure that this government is on the side of the arts community. We will ensure that where there are needs that can be met by government we will continue to meet them, and we will understand, as the opposition obviously do not, that there is a proper role to be played by government, not simply those who want to swan around as imperial leaders. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, would the government ever consider altering the boundaries of Kakadu National Park to permit uranium mining at Koongarra? Would the government ever permit uranium mining in a world heritage area? Will you rule out any such action?
—Why don't you give it to Warwick to answer? He runs environmental policy.
—Senator Schacht, cease interjecting.

—As the Senate would be aware, uranium mining is conducted on the Ranger lease in the vicinity of the Kakadu National Park, and approval has been given for a mining venture on the Jabiluka lease. As I said the other day, that will really be the mining of an ore body which will be processed on Ranger. The Koongarra lease is the third mining lease, to which the honourable senator referred. But the senator would also be aware that mining in Kakadu is illegal.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it true that the government is considering proclaiming the 1981 Koongarra Project Area Act?
—That has been floating around for a long time. I remember that the last two reports which I put to the parliament basically said that it is still floating around.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, I refer you to the government's new funding mechanism for schools, the enrolment benchmark adjustment, and your projections of late last year which estimated a rise in enrolments in non‐government schools from 29.4 to 31.7 per cent over the next four years. I refer also to the government's assurances that reliable census data would be available by the end of August, data upon which the EBA calculation for 1998 would be based, which would enable an accurate assessment of the cost of the EBA to government schools. I ask: has that census been completed? If not, why not, and when do you expect it to be completed? If it has been completed, what does it show? How much funding will your government be taking out of Australian state school systems over the next year and over the following three years through the application of the EBA to the census data?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth contributes under its schools programs more in non‐government schools than in government schools because the states, through their grants systems, fund government schools. That means that for every student who transfers from a government school to a non‐government school there is a cost shift to the Commonwealth government. This government introduced the enrolment benchmark adjustment which was to address that very measure. The enrolment benchmark adjustment is trigg ered when government schools do not maintain their enrolment share—and I stress `their enrolment share', not the particular numbers of those students enrolled; it has to be proportionate.

ANSWER.PARA: If government schools do not maintain their enrolment share, then the Commonwealth will recover half of the cost to the Commonwealth of that cost shift, which is half the amount of $3,400. In relation to the effect that that will have—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: I ask you to remind the minister that my question was about the census, not about the EBA.
—I remind you of the issue, Senator.

—Madam President, this is part of the answer. For the benefit of those senators opposite, I am telling them what this benchmark adjustment is doing and correcting the outrageous allegations that this will result in funding cuts of $270 million to government schools. That is just not the case. I have not seen the figures yet in relation to this census, but this estimate is totally incorrect. I was coming to that and I will continue with my answer.

ANSWER.PARA: The figure that has been quoted is highly inflated. It is important to stress that the correct figure for the four‐year period 1996 to the year 2000 is likely to be no more than $130 million. This benchmark adjustment factor will also take into account the effect that the youth allowance will have when it is introduced in July next year. But, as I say, the figures that have been touted of funding cuts of $270 million over the next four years are totally incorrect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I do not believe my question was answered and I will ask it again. Has the census been completed and, if not, why not? Minister, do you not think that 70 per cent of Australian parents with children in government schools are entitled to know precisely how much money the Howard government plans to take out of state school systems next year? When do you plan to inform those parents of the true impact of the enrolment benchmark adjustment? Will you make the census data publicly available?
—As I have said, I am not aware of that data as yet. When I have it, I will make it available.

—My question is addressed to Senator Alston as Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Does your government accept that companies who wish to bust unions are entitled to import gun‐toting vigilantes to assist them? If not, what action do you propose to take to put an end to this practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a classic question full of florid rhetoric. Of course, it did not condescend to detail about any particular circumstance or situation, so it requires an abstract answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it was asked in the abstract. The fact is that employers, owners of private property and those who control their own businesses are entitled to take reasonable steps to ensure that they are not subject to actions that might be—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get carried away! You started off very badly, but I am sure you can do a little better. It is understood in our society that where people have assets and resources they are entitled to protect them, and they are entitled to do that according to law. If they do not do that according to law, then I am sure that you and your clients will be the first to blow the whistle on them and make sure that they are prosecuted and dealt with in all sorts of ways. No doubt, even short of that, you would probably be quite happy to take other action as well. All I can say is that in general terms there is no reason why people should not take action that is necessary to protect their own businesses. Those who think that somehow they ought to be subsumed in the greater interest of protecting the trade union movement have got another think coming.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Alston, the place in question is Emerald in Queensland. There has been wide publicity about the use of vigilantes there. My question to you remains: does the government accept that companies that wish to bust unions are entitled to import gun‐toting vigilantes to assist them? Also, how do you respond to the concerns of the residents of the town of Emerald about the tension in the town caused by the importation of such vigilantes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are talking about the Gordonstone coalmine in Queensland, I am aware that issues were raised in the Sunday program in relation to the alleged actions of the management at the Gordonstone coalmine. It is necessary to have the full story before one jumps to any conclusions, and I think the last people you would look to for an objective assessment of what is going on there are those who clearly have a vested interest in portraying this as not only anti‐union but antisocial.

ANSWER.PARA: A media release, which I presume Senator Hogg has seen, was put out on 19 October in which the company said that staff safety is a priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You can laugh—that is fairly typical, isn't it? In other words, it is a presumption of guilt. You say: any company that has the temerity to say, `We are interested in the safety of our employees,' must be lying, must somehow not be interested at all, must be doing quite the opposite. That is what George Orwell said: you say one thing and therefore you mean the opposite. (Time expired)

—Madam President, my question is to you. I note that there has been a threat to national security; in particular, to Australia's long‐term economic advantage through developing energy alternatives by the Prime Minister rejecting energy efficiency and not accepting Greenpeace's kind offer of the solar panels which were put on Kirribilli House yesterday.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note, apropos of alternative energy, that the parliament achieved a 40 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions between 1989 and now. Minister, I refer to your assertion in question time yesterday that no‐one had paid anything like $90,000 to enter a nursing home. Are you aware that earlier this month the Ginninderra Gardens nursing home in Canberra charged $125,000 in order to admit a new resident? Are you further aware that former Minister Moylan was informed of the details of this case? Minister, why did you mislead the Senate yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again. It is very interesting to get this sort of question from Senator Faulkner. Obviously, I was unaware of the statement. I would not accept that statement at face value in any case, but that is a statement of Senator Faulkner and I will check it. I was obviously unaware of the statement you have made. But more important is to look at what Labor did. Look at what happened under Labor.
—Senator, you should not be holding up papers in the chamber.
—I will put it down, Madam President.
—Incorporate it!

—May I incorporate it, Madam President? They do not want it incorporated. I will table it. Capital expenditure under Labor went down precipitously over that period of time. I have another graph which shows that the new approvals, in principle, did the same thing. For the benefit of my own backbenchers, I think they should be aware of what went on under Labor.
—You have got it upside down and back to front.
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—Order! Senator Schacht!

—What we are addressing is the neglect that occurred under Labor. I wanted to demonstrate that with those graphs to show graphically what has occurred. What is Labor's answer? I have here what Jenny Macklin said today on Radio National. Labor is saying that that capital expenditure should be raised through the tax system. More tax!

BREAK.PARA: Come back, Cheryl! She has joined not new Labor, but old Labor. She has jumped into the cesspit of old Labor. She has not realised it. The great seducer is sitting in the front there, the one that had the coffee pot. She did not realise that it is old Labor we are dealing with—the old high‐tax Labor. That is their answer to these problems.

Under the principle that Senator Faulkner had in relation to hostels, there was no cap. So, following the same principle, there is no cap in this. It is an agreement between the person going into the nursing home and the proprietor.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—I am pleased to hear that it is finally getting through to the other side. It is an agreement between the nursing home proprietor and the person going into the nursing home.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party let the capital expenditure in nursing homes go down rapidly. They did not address the problem. They ignored the fact that there is a rapidly ageing population in this country. They ignored the fact that nursing homes were being neglected and, I said yesterday, that 40 per cent of people in nursing homes are in wards with four or more beds. What is their answer? When they come into government they will tax people. They will have more tax.

What we are doing is fair and equitable. We are charging those who can afford to pay to go into nursing homes. It is a fair and equitable solution to the problem. We have to adopt a statesmanlike attitude in this regard rather than an expedient attitude or the populism that the Labor Party is proposing.

There are problems in relation to nursing homes. This gives me the opportunity—I hope that Senator Faulkner comes up with a supplementary question because I need a little extra time—to enunciate the principles under which this policy is being put forward. I appreciate that time is running out. I would appreciate a supplementary question so that I can give further answer to this question from Senator Faulkner. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My supplementary question to Senator Herron is this: Minister, if you did not mislead the Senate yesterday, will you now repeat your assertion in this chamber today that no-one has paid anything like $90,000 or, if you did mislead the Senate yesterday, in accordance with the Prime Minister's code of ministerial responsibility, will you now apologise to the parliament and the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mislead the Senate yesterday. I had stated that of those approvals that had come forward there was no figure of $90,000. That was a fact, as I was informed yesterday. Senator Denman asked me a question yesterday, and I said that, if there is information that the opposition has where there are anomalies occurring, we will address them. There are problems around the fringes, of course.
—What are they?

—I asked Senator Denman yesterday to come forward with information and she has not come forward. I gave her the opportunity. She has had 24 hours to bring forward these anomalies, and she has not brought them forward.

BREAK.PARA: So it is all very well for Senator Faulkner to get up and talk about anomalies that are occurring, but he has not come forward with any. We have asked for information from the other side; we have asked for any anomalies that occur because we will address them. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, evidence presented to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee inquiry into the sugar tariff recently revealed that canefarmers' incomes will drop by an average of $3,000 a year from the loss of the sugar tariff. It was also made clear that the canefarmers' loss will be passed on to multinational soft drink processors such as Coca-Cola. It is nice to know the government is all about helping battlers like the Coca-Cola company. Minister, why is your government determined to increase the profits of multinational companies at the expense of Australian farmers?

—Senator Woodley either has a bad memory or he is short on questions because this is the second time he has asked this question in about the last four or five weeks. However, to assist Senator Woodley and maybe improve his memory, I would point out that some sectors of the sugar industry have expressed concerns over the government's decision to remove the tariff on sugar imports in the light of subsequent decisions in other industry sectors. As you are aware, the government's decision on sugar tariffs was one of the recommendations of the sugar industry review working party, which were made and supported unanimously by members of the working party so long as their recommendations were endorsed in toto.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Woodley may remember that a very important thing for the sugar industry was single desk selling. I would remind Senator Woodley that the package has already received the support of the Queensland government, which has a consuming interest in this—if you will excuse the expression. The government endorsed the full package as a necessary step towards an internationally competitive and sustainable industry. These measures will position the industry to meet future challenges and competition. Nevertheless, Minister Anderson has pointed out that he understands the concern of the industry at the possible short-term impact of the decision to remove the tariff and that this impact may vary from region to region. However, the longer term interests and prosperity of the Australian industry have to be borne in mind.

If I recall correctly, when I last answered this question for Senator Woodley I pointed out to him that in Queensland—I think he referred to Queensland in his question—some 90 per cent of the sugar is exported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty-five.

—Eighty-five. In fact, Senator Boswell corrected me last time. It went from 80 to 85. It has gone from 90 back to 85. He would be aware, as with most of the primary industries, that that is the sort of percentage that is exported. It is in the order of 80 to 90 per cent, whereas we consume the rest domestically, compared with other countries, where the consumption is mainly a domestic consumption. I am not talking about sugar; I am talking about the whole primary industries area. Therefore, we in this country, from a primary industry perspective, have a vested interest in removing tariff and non-tariff barriers to help the exports of our primary industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you did not even go close. Let me try again. Mr Tony Gentile—

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Boswell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would ask you the question, Senator Boswell, because I know you would know the answer, but I am afraid I cannot do that. Mr Tony Gentile, head of the Australasian Soft Drink Association, admitted to the committee that his industry will be $7 million better off from the removal of the tariff but will not pass on the saving to customers. Minister, what happened to the benefits that were supposed to flow on to consumers from the removal of the sugar tariff? What is your government doing to make sure that big companies pass on to ordinary Australians the savings from sugar tariff reductions?

—Senator Woodley said he was trying, and I agree with him. As I pointed out to Senator Woodley in my response, the primary industry sector in Australia has a vested interest in removing tariff and non-tariff barriers so that we can get entry into foreign markets. We need to expand our foreign markets. I do not think anyone would disagree with that. The other point I make to you, Senator—and I just give this as an example—is: why would it be cheaper with a tariff to make chocolates in New Zealand than in Australia? That is the effect—

—On a point of order, Madam President: I did not interrupt the first answer, although it was totally irrelevant. On the question of relevance, I am not here to answer the minister's questions. It would be good if he would even try to give one answer to the questions I have asked.
—There is no point of order.

—There are twofold benefits coming from the tariff matter. First of all, as I pointed out in answer to the question, it was agreed with the industry provided the package was taken in toto. It realises that there is some short-term pain involved but it also sees the long-term benefits. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, can you confirm that the 25 September ANTA memorandum of understanding between the states and the Commonwealth asserts that Minco will determine and set the guidelines for bilateral discussions between ANTA and each state and territory, and will agree the outcomes of those discussions? Is it the case that Minco is set to meet on 14 November 1997 to sign the next ANTA agreement? Have those draft guidelines been developed? Have draft levels of growth through so-called efficiencies been established with each state and territory?

—Senator Carr, at this moment Commonwealth and state officials are working on the revised ANTA agreement. You are right: back in September ANTA Minco did agree to do that. That is being progressed at the moment. As I said to you yesterday, the former minister in my position, Dr Kemp, was unable to set—and did not set—any figures on estimates of growth, as opposed to how that might relate to efficiencies, because this had to be worked through with the states. As was stated in that communique and that agreement, we will look at each state on a case by case basis because of the different or prevailing circumstances that affected them. So at this stage it is being worked through. Hopefully, it will be resolved by 14 November, when the next meeting of the council takes place.

Minister, is it the case that the Commonwealth has completely backed down on its demands for an additional 500,000 TAFE places? Given that the new ANTA agreement is due to come into operation in January next year and that the proposed school education choices are being contemplated right now, isn't it incumbent upon the government to advise the Australian public of the guidelines relating to the allocation of ANTA funds for TAFE next year?

—I fail to see how consulting with the states and working through this is a hopeless situation. In fact, it is the very thing the states have been calling for. Senator Carr, it is entirely appropriate—in fact, more so, responsible of this government—to be doing that with the state governments at this point in time. The next meeting is not that far away. We will have the meet ing on that day and we are working through it at this very moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Will the minister advise the Senate about the government's initiative to encourage greater efficiency in the operation of coal fired power stations in China? What are the implications of this assistance for achieving significant global reductions in greenhouse gas emissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Payne for that question. It is a very important question. I am pleased to advise the Senate that I have approved a grant to Pacific Power International to enable the company to work with Zhejiang Provincial Electrical Power Company in China to improve the economic and environmental performance of power generation.

ANSWER.PARA: The two power companies will take part in a power plant improvement study to identify low cost solutions to improve the efficiency and greenhouse performance of existing Chinese power stations. The study will also demonstrate the capabilities of Australian industry to improve economic and environmental performance through the supply of high quality Australian coals and, equally—or more importantly—Australian clean coal technology and advice. I might point out to the Senate that the current production of coal in China is about 1.3 billion tonnes, with plans to extend that to about 1.5 billion tonnes, compared to Australia's production of about 240 million tonnes. So that gives you some idea of the differences in production.

The study will make an important contribution to demonstrating Australia's commitment to help develop China's power sector in an environmentally responsible way. The importance of coal as an essential energy fuel in China's developments, and as Australia's largest export commodity, underlines the importance of initiatives of this nature. The alternative is that China will employ far fewer greenhouse friendly technologies and will consume ever increasing quantities of very low quality domestic coal. The study is expected to be completed in 1998.

Improving power station performance in Asian developing economies is a cost‐effective way of achieving very large reductions in global greenhouse gas emissions. Refurbishing Asia's inefficient coal power stations has the potential to reduce C02 emissions by approximately 60 million tonnes, which is around half of Australia's total emissions from all its coal fired power stations.

By early next century, the total greenhouse gas emissions of large developing countries driven by those experiencing rapid economic growth will overtake those of developed countries. These developing country emissions are projected to grow by about four per cent a year while developed country emissions are projected to grow by about 1.3 per cent over the next several decades.

In China's case alone, carbon dioxide emissions in the energy sector are projected by the International Energy Agency to grow over the next two decades from about a quarter of the OECD emissions and just over 10 per cent of global emissions to about 40 per cent of OECD emissions, about one-sixth of total global emissions. An international greenhouse abatement agreement must deal with this degree of emissions growth in developing countries if it is to be effective, and Australia is pressing for equitable and achievable objectives at Kyoto that will encourage the eventual participation of developing countries in a truly global response to a global issue.

This new cooperative initiative with China is a tangible demonstration that win‐win solutions to difficult issues can be found. Our industry wins through new investment and technology development opportunities. The partner government—China, in this case—and industry certainly win. Above all, the environment is the ultimate winner. This is the government's approach, and it is one of which we should all be proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked two questions by Senator Gibbs in relation to someone who rented their home for $450 a week to pay a periodic accommodation bond. I have an answer to that question and a question from Senator Denman asking whether accommodation bonds paid as periodic payments were protected by the prudential fund or whether providers could do as they like with them. I seek leave to incorporate the answers.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The answers read as follows—

Senator Gibbs asked two questions in relation to someone who rented their home for $450 a week to pay a periodic accommodation bond. If the home was rented, capital gains tax would be very unlikely to apply. If the home was purchased before 20 September 1985, it would never apply. If it was purchased after that date, there are exemptions.

CGT is not payable where someone is temporarily away from the home for less than six years, such as in nursing home, even if they rented it. If they died in the nursing home and the house was inherited by the family, this inheritance is not counted as disposal for CGT purposes. CGT would only be payable if the home was purchased after 20 September 1985 and it was sold while they were in the nursing home, after having been there for 6 years.

As to whether the person would lose their pension or not, this would depend entirely on what other income they had. If they had little other private income, they probably wouldn't lose their pension. Centrelink will allow 33 per cent of the gross rental income as expenses, or more, if appropriate. The income that would count under the pension income test would be below the cut-off for the pension.

The answer is "no" on both counts. The payments are not covered by the prudential fund because they are not refundable—they are regular payments which are equivalent to the retention and interest earned on a lump sum. So there is no reason for them to be paid to the prudential fund—they are equivalent to the income stream that would be paid by the prudential fund to the provider.

And the provider cannot do as they like with periodic payments. Income from accommodation bonds must be used, in the first instance, to support capital improvements or related debt retirement and, secondly, where further capital investment is not reasonably required to meet accreditation or certification, to improve the range and quality of aged care services.
Either way, the resident benefits—that is the purpose of accommodation bonds.

SPEECH.PARA: This crisis has been going a whole month. But the crisis would not be there if this government had some decent industrial relations laws which would see the resolution of problems. The thuggery that Senator Crane spoke about was quite unfair and quite un called for when describing my colleague Senator Mackay.

TALK.START.PARA: —And unparliamentary.

—Yes and that is another issue. I can assure you of one thing: these vigilantes do resort to thuggery, they do resort to quite underhanded means of securing the aim for the companies in the end. In effect, if this government had decent IR laws then we would not have this problem in Emerald today. The truth of the matter is that the government does not want the problem resolved. This government feeds on this sort of thing because it builds up a picture out there in the community that there really is a problem.

SPEECH.PARA: American‐type laws and American anti-unionism destroys rights and dignities and we certainly do not want that here. The government's approach to IR—and that is the real point of all of this—is a complete and utter farce. The nub of the problem for these people is that they are interested in their own job security. That is why they are fighting back, and if people do not fight back when job security is at stake when do they fight? They want to protect their livelihoods, their families. They do not want to be spied upon. They do not want to be stalked. They certainly want the right to defend their own rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been invited to accept the proposition that the union movement has the right to impose its wish and whim on the Australian community, irrespective of the laws of the land. That is something we would reject very strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the two previous speakers, I have been to Emerald on many occasions and I have also regrettably been in Emerald and the central Queensland coalfields when some very nasty strikes by the same people have taken place in the past. I find it just incredible that Senator Hogg and Senator Mackay can stand up here with a straight face and talk about intimidation by security guards at the mine properties. I can tell you that when these sorts of people are out rampaging on the streets and running the picket lines you are very lucky to get away without a broken skull if you are not a miner up there. It is a very ugly scene.

BREAK.PARA: Let us get to the heart of the argument. The heart of the argument is not about wages and conditions or anything like that; it is about productivity. It is about getting from some of the lowest levels of production per worker in these mines with the best equipment in the world up to what is a reasonable world standard so that those miners can continue to receive the high wages they get.

All we have seen today from the opposition in the Senate is some archaic defence of the right of union thuggery. I am sorry, but you cannot do that today. While we are on the subject of thuggery, what do you say about somebody who goes in and bugs the managing director's house? It certainly was not the company who bugged the managing director's house. I think it is a pretty fair proposition that the union movement went in there and bugged his house.

What the union movement is on about is not wanted by the majority of Australians. If the Labor Party were in touch with the Australian community, they would know they are pushing something that has no support in the community at all. Most Australians recognise that we live by a rule of law and they are prepared to see that rule of law changed through the proper place, which is this parliament. They know very well that if they take the law into their hands then the law of the jungle prevails.

At the opening of this parliament we saw exactly the same union, I think, involved in that terrible incident of absolute anarchy where they did more than one‐quarter of a million dollars worth of damage to the entrance of this parliament. These are the same people, the rent‐a‐crowd mob from the union movement, that Senator Mackay and Senator Hogg are so strongly defending today.

It is time the Jennie Georges and the John Maitlands of this world realised that they are out of step with society. That is why the union membership has collapsed. The membership is down to about one-third of what it was when I joined the work force and when I was a union member—and I am one of the few people in this place on this side of the chamber who has been an active union member.

There is a better way of doing things than the Labor Party way of confrontation, standoverism and intimidation. We do not want to see us go down that path. Let us reason together. If workers have a problem with management about their terms and conditions, they should sit down and talk to management. If they cannot reach a mutually satisfactory position, then the workers have every right to move on and find another employer who will accommodate them. But they have no right to take to the streets, to close down the works and prevent them working.

For Senator Hogg to say that the government does not want the mine to produce is an absolute nonsense. I do not know the value of the Arco mine there but there might well be a capital investment of several hundred million dollars. Every day and every hour that the mine does not work costs the owners big money. They certainly want to see this mine in production and they are certainly entitled to go about their business of running that mine the way they wish to run it for the benefit of their own investors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen George

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what program Senator MacGibbon watched but his comments were not in reference to the Sunday program and the contents of that program in relation to what was occurring at the Gordonstone mine in Emerald because the program had nothing to do with the dispute. In fact it spent very little time talking about the actual dispute at the mine or the fact that 300 workers had been sacked. The program was about describing what could only be described as overt intimidation of a group of people in a country town for no other purpose than to drive them out of their homes, drive them out of the town and open the door to bring in a new set of non-union labour. That is the strategy behind what was described on the Sunday program. The company had gone about hiring a group of thugs—and that is the only way you can describe these people—professionals—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had watched the program, Senator Mac Gibbon, you would know they were professionals. They were very cool under pressure. They did not panic when they were confronted by the people from the gun club. They did not panic when they were threatened by the TV cameras. They new exactly what they were doing. They were trained professionals who were there to do a job of intimidation upon those people. They were moving around that town very openly, very overtly, to make sure every one in the town knew that they were there.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the aftermath of a dispute that has essentially been generated by your industrial relations reform. It comes directly out of your AWAs and the reform of industrial relations implemented by your government, and that is very clear. Let us look at what this company said five years ago when it was operating under a different industrial relations system—when it was operating under an industrial relations system that was about trying to create cooperation in the workplace, trying to get workers and management to work together to build productivity in the workplace and to get better productivity and better outcomes for the Australian economy.

This company produced a video describing its operation at Gordonstone. What do the opening words of the song in that video say? They say, `Gordonstone miners are the world's best mining team.' They were the opening words of the song in the video produced by this company. Yet three or four years later we have the same company saying, `This is the world's worst mining team. We've got to get rid of them out of the mine,' and they sacked 300 of them. They say, `Not only have we got to get them out of the mine, we've got to drive them out of the town.' That is what this agenda is all about. They have to drive them out of their homes and get them away from the place and open the doors for non-union labour.

What has changed over that three- or four‐year period? What has changed has been the introduction of your industrial relations reforms which are saying to companies, `Don't worry about negotiations. Don't worry about trying to work with your work force. We will support you in taking whatever action you want to take in order to get the changes you want to implement in the workplace.'

The only thing that shocks me about what is occurring at Gordonstone is that one of the minority shareholders in that mine is Lend Lease, a company that had a history of good industrial relations in this country. I do not know what influence they can bring to bear on that dispute or what is occurring in that area, but if they can they ought to be trying to exert whatever influence they can to try to turn the situation around in that place.

The reality is that you have introduced industrial relations reform in this country which was bred out of the 19th century. It is the type of industrial relations we saw in this country in the 1890s when we saw shearers shot because they dared to take strike action to defend their rights. We are seeing the same type of intimidation recurring in the 1990s. A famous philosopher once said events occur in history twice: the first time as tragedy and the second time as farce. What is occurring in Gordonstone is an absolute farce which is perpetrated and generated by your industrial relations reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —You welcomed the person into the Labor Party; you have welcomed Kernot.
—One has to ask the question, because it begs to be asked: what encouragement is this company getting from the industrial relations minister for the activities it is undertaking? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should take up Senator Harradine's point first. He is making the point to Senator George Campbell that they have just welcomed into their ranks the former Senator Kernot who utterly and thoroughly endorsed and negotiated the whole industrial relations law. It puts paid to—and we on this side of the chamber utterly reject—any spurious link you have tried to make with the government's industrial relations law and the problems in Emerald.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know the issue any more than you it seems. We all may have seen the Sunday program. We all should not base our outrages and our evidence on what the media will put on a program. I saw the Sunday program like everyone else. I would have thought that, if you really did have a case that there were the problems that you are putting forward today, you would have had more evidence than just what you saw last Sunday on the Sunday program. But you have latched on to the issue, you are beating it up for all it is worth and you have come up with no more than what the Sunday program in all its drama produced.

I thought you could have done better than that. If you really were serious, you would have come up with better speakers than you have. Honestly. Senator George Campbell has tried to carry the case for the opposition. Senator Campbell is in the ranks of John Halfpenny and Wally Curran. He is from the old days when this sort of thuggery behaviour was quite common.

TALK.START.PARA: —And proud of it.
—`And proud of it' he says, `And proud of it.' He is proud of—
—Senator McGauran, you might like to address your remarks through the chair. That might save some of the interjections.

—Senator Campbell does bring it out in me, Madam Deputy President. He is proud of the fact that he belongs to those dinosaur days of the union movement, which today's union movement is paying a very high price for, given the membership collapse that they are now suffering. He is proud of those days of well-known thuggery on the wharves, in the meatworks and of course in the manufacturers union, unto which you only have 100,000 unemployed people around your neck.

SPEECH.PARA: We could go tit for tat with regard to stories being told of thuggery on the union side. We could, for example, look at the waterfront. They will shut the nation down at the drop of a hat costing our export income hundreds of millions of dollars. Most of them within that union are shadowy characters. The threat of strike is always hanging above our rural sector in particular, the sector that I represent. That threat is always standing over them. Those on the waterfront would prefer the exports to rot on the wharves than that union be upset in any way at all.

Such is the tit for tat we can go for. If there is a problem in those coalfields, as you have put it, give us a bit of real hard evidence. Don't run it off a TV show. We do not accept any link with our industrial relations laws. But if there is this sort of thuggery and gun carrying that you are talking about, well look into it. We do not accept that sort of behaviour in this country at all, but don't try to link it with our industrial relations laws. In fact, when it comes to defending our industrial relations laws, I am only too pleased to have the opportunity to do so.

There are certain parts of that industrial relations law—supported by the Democrats, I might add, and I will add that many times over every time we get a chance—that you have never been able to accept because, in many respects, it goes to the heart of the union's past thuggery behaviour. For example, the secondary boycott—the introduction of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. That has been specifically introduced to prevent the thuggery of unions ganging up against one employer and putting them out of business. Of course, the masters of that were the waterfront workers.

The opposition have never been able to accept the freedom of association that we have introduced. That should be a basic right for any worker: they either want to join a union or not. You used to bully workers into the union. You used to drive them out of the workplace unless they joined a union. These are just two incidences that we have addressed in our industrial relations legislation which prevent the old‐time thuggery of the unions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are still the only Australians, sent overseas on active service, whose service has not been recognised in three important areas:
1. R.A.N. casualties are not yet included on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial alongside Army and R.A.A.F. casualties;
2. R.A.N. service has not yet been recognised with the visible signs of service to Australia; the Returned from Active Service Badge and the Naval campaign medal; and
3. R.A.N. service is still not acknowledged as eligible service for the Australian Service Pension, while service by Commonwealth and allied veterans from 55 other countries is.
Members of the Army and R.A.A.F. who served during the same period in Malaya had their service fully recognised 24 hours after arriving in Malaya.

In the 1997 Budget the Government partly recognised that R.A.N. service was `operational' and accepted responsibility for disabilities resulting from that service. However, government departments are still resorting to old, and inventing new excuses, to deny the above 3 points.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate acts to help remove the injustice of 40 years and fully recognise R.A.N. service by providing the same recognition and benefits for that service. The cost will be minuscule, being mainly a transfer of pensions from `age' as paid by the Department of Social Security, to `service' pensions, paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned request that the Australian Senate implements the following:
A Senate enquiry into the use of genetic engineering in the Australian Food Supply, including the ethics of its use.
That consultations be undertaken with the general public to ask if we want this technology in our food supply and consent to its use.
That consumers be resourced to attend these consultations.
Any food that is genetically engineered or contains components that are genetically engineered are required to be labelled, including the origin of the genes.
That meaningful right to know legislation be enacted to guarantee public access to toxicology data.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Allison, Sen Lyn; Brown, Sen Bob
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Allison(from 200 citizens)and Senator Brown(from 216 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Timed Local Calls
PETITION.PARA: A Petition to the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain residents in the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the Senate the harsh and regressive decision by the Howard Government to allow telecommunications carriers to charge timed local calls for data communication services such as electronic mail, facsimile, the internet and other on‐line services. This measure will adversely affect business and individual users of the above services, and particularly hamper the operations and growth of small business.
Your petitioners call on the Senate to request that the Howard Government rescind their decision, and ensure local data communication services are charged on an untimed basis.

PETITION.TITLE: Darwin to Adelaide Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia showeth that:
We are concerned with the outstanding debt owed to South Australia by the Commonwealth Government of Australia for South Australia's investment in Northern Territory.
Payment of this debt was to be in the form of a railway line from Darwin to Adelaide as a legislated agreement passed by Parliament in 1910 called the Northern Territory Acceptance Act 1910.

We have waited 87 years for the Commonwealth Government to honour and complete its obligation to the citizens of South Australia, and your petitioners therefore pray that this House will take all appropriate steps to ensure the fulfilment of this obligation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Live Cattle Exports

The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That we condemn the growth in live cattle exports, and support the motion endorsed at a public meeting held in Townsville on Monday 20th March 1995, calling for a moratorium on such live cattle exports until a full investigation reveals what effect the live cattle trade is having on the Australian economy, unemployment, and the welfare of the animals.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should seek to:
1. Impose a moratorium on live cattle exports
2. Instigate a review into the live cattle export industry and its effect on the North Queensland community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and a correction to the explanatory memorandum and move:

I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—
INTRODUCTION

BREAK.PARA: The National Environment Protection Measures (Implementation) Bill represents a further significant milestone in the development of environment protection in Australia. The bill represents a commitment of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories to work cooperatively to develop and implement national environment protection measures, a commitment which was agreed to by the Council of Australian Governments in the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment in May 1992.

It bears repeating that the objectives of the measures are to ensure that people, wherever they live in Australia, enjoy the benefit of equivalent protection from air, water, soil pollution and noise and secondly, to ensure that decisions by business are not distorted and markets are not fragmented by variations between jurisdictions in relation to the adoption or implementation of major environment protection measures.

The bill is the second part of a package of complementary State and Commonwealth legislation. It follows the National Environment Protection Council Act 1994 which established the National Environment Protection Council and allowed for the development and application of national environment protection measures. National environment protection measures, which may be a combination of goals, guidelines, standards or protocols, will apply as valid law in each participating jurisdiction.

The first face‐to‐face meeting of the Council occurred on 21 June 1996, after the States and Territories had passed mirror legislation to put in place commitments to implement national environment protection measures.
The National Environment Protection Council Act 1994 determined that measures may be made in relation to:
(a) ambient air quality
(b) ambient marine, estuarine and fresh water quality;
(c) noise, where differences in environmental requirements relating to noise would have an adverse effect on national markets for goods and services;
(d) general guidelines for the assessment of site contamination;
(e) environmental impacts associated with hazardous wastes;
(f) the re‐use and recycling of used materials;
(g) motor vehicles noise and emissions, also where differences in standards would affect national markets.

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE OPERATION OF THE BILL

BREAK.PARA: The purpose of the National Environment Protection Measures (Implementation) Bill is to provide for the implementation of national environment protection measures in respect of activities by the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities.
The bill provides the means by which the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities are able to implement national environment protection measures. These means consist of:
. the application of provisions of State and Territory laws;
. the making of regulations;
. the use of an existing law of the Commonwealth which can deliver appropriate environmental outcomes; and
. the carrying out of an environmental audit and preparation of an environment management plan.

National environment protection measures relating to ambient air quality, the National Pollutant Inventory, transport of hazardous wastes across State and Territory borders, the assessment of contaminated sites and diesel emissions are presently being developed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: COOPERATION WITH STATES AND TERRITORIES IN ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT

BREAK.PARA: The bill is breaking new ground and will establish stronger co‐operation between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories in relation to environment protection initiatives. The bill is being implemented concurrently with an examination of the division of responsibilities for the environment in the present Review of Commonwealth and State Roles and Responsibilities for the Environment. Among other things, the Review is examining the Commonwealth's compliance with State and Territory environment and planning laws consistent with the principles of competitive neutrality as agreed by the Council of Australian Governments.

It is envisaged that the mechanism of application of State and Territory laws will be the first option considered for the implementation of a national environment protection measure with regard to Commonwealth activities and sites.

PARA.EMPHASIS: COMPLIANCE WITH THE MEASURES

BREAK.PARA: The Commonwealth, and the States and Territories will have to comply with any national environment protection measure developed by the National Environment Protection Council. This strong commitment by all governments ensures national harmonisation of approaches which aim to protect the environment. The National Environment Protection Measures (Implementation) Bill is the mechanism through which the Commonwealth will fulfil this important commitment.

An exemption from implementing a particular measure at a certain Commonwealth place or with regard to a specific Commonwealth activity will ONLY be given on the ground of a matter of national interest. A matter of `national interest' is confined to:
(i) Australia's relations with another country or Australia's international obligations, national security, national defence or a national emergency; or

(ii) a matter relating to telecommunications or the management of aviation airspace and airports, including aircraft emissions, aircraft noise and on‐ground airport management, but not including matters specified by 1.04 (2) of the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations; or
(iii) any other matter agreed to between the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories.

Australia is part of an international aviation community and it is the Government's view that matters relating to aviation airspace management and airport management would benefit from being regulated under a single national regime. In providing an holistic regime for the effective environmental regulation for airspace and airports, the Commonwealth will be meeting the Objectives of NEPMs provided by the IGAE.

The bill provides for the implementation of NEPMs by another law of the Commonwealth if the Environment Minister is satisfied it will achieve appropriate environmental outcomes. One of the Objects of the Airport (Environmental Protection) Regulations, made under the Airports Act 1996, is to establish, in conjunction with NEPMs, a Commonwealth system of regulation for activities at airports that generate, or have the potential to generate, pollution or excessive noise. By operating in conjunction with NEPMs, it is my view that the Regulations will provide the appropriate environmental outcomes.
To ensure these outcomes are achieved, the Regulations prescribe the development of an environment strategy for each airport and the establishment of an enforcement regime.

Noise emissions from aircraft in flight or when landing, taking off or taxiing at an airport and engine emissions will continue to be regulated by the Air Navigation (Aircraft Noise) Regulations and the Air Navigation (Aircraft Engine Emissions) Regulations respectively which will continue to meet Australia's international obligations.

In the case where State or Territory law is not the mechanism for implementation of a particular national environment protection measure, there is an obligation on the part of Commonwealth authorities to implement the measure either through an existing Commonwealth law which will deliver the necessary environmental outcomes, through Commonwealth regulations or through development of an environment management plan.

Non‐compliance with a national environment protection measure will be published in the Gazette, and the details of authorities not complying will also be publicly available through the annual report to Parliament on implementation of the measures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RIGOROUS DEVELOPMENT OF THE MEASURES

BREAK.PARA: In developing a national environment protection measure, regional environmental differences must be taken into account, as must the environmental, economic and social impacts of the measure. The Council must also take into account whether the measure is the most effective means of achieving the desired environmental outcome, and whether the measure can be simply and effectively administered.
National environment protection measures must also be consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development as outlined in the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.

As stated earlier, the National Environment Protection Council is developing draft measures for the National Pollutant Inventory and ambient air quality. Both these measures aim to address issues of national significance. The Government made an election commitment to develop a National Pollutant Inventory and ambient air standards, and I have made programs which seek to make our cities sustainable a priority for my Portfolio. Development of a measure for ambient air quality recognises the intense community concerns about air pollution.

A number of studies have been undertaken to ensure that the current measures being developed, for the National Pollutant Inventory and ambient air quality, can stand up to rigorous scrutiny, both in relation to their scientific basis and administrative efficiency as well as their effectiveness in contributing to achieving the desired environmental outcome. For example, the Government's Air Pollution Inquiry is assisting the development of the Ambient Air Quality measure through the funding of important work on air quality standards.

An impact statement is required for each national environment protection measure by the National Environment Protection Council Act 1994. These impact statements will comprise comprehensive explanations of the measure and identify where possible economic, environmental or social costs or benefits are likely to arise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: NON‐GOVERNMENT INVOLVEMENT IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF MEASURES

BREAK.PARA: Public consultation is an important component of the process to develop measures. Draft measures will be published in the Commonwealth Gazette and submissions regarding the draft measure invited over a two month period.

Non‐government advisory groups, with membership relevant to the various national environment protection measures, have been involved in the development of those measures. Membership of these groups has included representatives of groups as diverse as the Australian Institute of Petroleum, Minerals Council of Australia, ACTU, Greenpeace Australia and the Queensland Conservation Council.
Non‐Government representatives have also participated in the technical advisory panels for national environment protection measures.

Further, the community will have an opportunity to examine each draft measure and to provide submissions during the consultation period following publication of the draft measure in the Commonwealth Gazette. It is very likely that changes will be made to the national environment protection measures after receiving important feedback from various sources during the public consultation phase.
The draft measure for the National Pollutant Inventory has been released for public consultation while the ambient air quality measure was released as a public discussion paper.
Passage of this bill will help spur on the development of these national environment protection measures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: HARMONISATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES ACROSS AUSTRALIA

BREAK.PARA: An outcome of the adoption of national environment protection measures will be greater certainty for business, and a greater capacity for industry to manage environmental issues which cross State borders.

While implementation strategies may vary somewhat across States and Territories, it is likely that information will be shared between jurisdictions in relation to implementation of measures and that, over time, the implementation strategies themselves will have a tendency to become uniform nationally.

PARA.EMPHASIS: CONCLUSION

BREAK.PARA: The passage of the National Environmental Protection Measures (Implementation) Bill is a landmark event for environmental management in Australia. The legislation will provide the implementation vehicle for the development of national environment protection measures on, as I have mentioned previously, a range of issues including air and water pollution, contaminated sites assessment, the transport of hazardous wastes across borders, in some instances, motor vehicle emissions, and the re‐use and recycling of used materials.

Cooperation between the Commonwealth and State and Territory governments in the development of measures represents a major benefit not only to the people of Australia and to the environment, but also to Australian industry.

There will be benefits to the environment through the close attention given to the specific environment issues and to identifying an effective environmental outcome in development of national environment protection measures. The Australian people will benefit through having access to equivalent protection from pollutants wherever they live in Australia, and industry will benefit from ensuring competitive neutrality in relation to their activities throughout Australia.

Even though the current agenda for the measures is relatively extensive, there may be calls in the future to extend the range of measures which can be dealt with under the National Environment Protection Council Act.

However, for the moment, we can look forward to the early development of an ambient air quality measure, the National Pollutant Inventory measure, a measure on the transport of hazardous wastes across State or Territory borders and one on guidelines for assessment of contaminated sites. The work required for the development of a measure is extensive and resources have been stretched in all jurisdictions to develop the first measures for ambient air quality and the National Pollutant Inventory, which I hope will be finalised and gazetted in February 1998 ready for the implementation phase.
I commend the National Environmental Protection Measures (Implementation) Bill to you as an important achievement in environmental management for Australia and for all Australians.
