SPEECH.PARA: APPENDIX 1

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE BY DR CLIVE HAMILTON
AGREED TO BY DR HAMILTON AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(B) OF THE SENATE OF 28 FEBRUARY 1988
Reply to Senator Parer

SPEECH.PARA: In 1994 I was invited by Caroline Jones to be a guest on her ABC Radio program The Search for Meaning. The Search for Meaning was a long‐running program that provided an opportunity for well‐known people to discuss their personal spiritual and religious journeys. It was difficult for me to decide whether to accept the invitation to appear because it would require some very intimate revelations about my own spiritual journey. I feared that I may be misunderstood and, possibly, ridiculed by people who have little understanding of powerful spiritual experiences. After the program, I had many letters and telephone calls from people around Australia thanking me for my willingness to speak of these issues.

Senator Parer has selected from the one‐hour interview my description of the stage of the spiritual journey known as the `confrontation with the shadow', a well‐known aspect of the process of `individuation', that is, the process of achieving psychological wholeness. There is an extensive psychological literature on this process.

Many eminent Australians—including authors, scientists, poets, academics and religious leaders—have spoken or written of similar experiences, as any regular listener of Caroline Jones' program would know. The experience of confronting the shadow is a persistent theme of the world's literature. Some celebrated examples include Goethe's Faust and Dante's Inferno. I could name dozens more which deal with it explicitly. The theme also figures prominently in Australian literature including the work of A. D. Hope and Patrick White, the latter in his seminal work Voss, to name but two.

This literature in turn reflects the graphic treatment of these experiences in the great religious writings of the world. They feature prominently in both the old and new testaments of the Bible and in the Bhagavad‐Gita, to mention only two. Several of the best‐known Christian theologians, including St John of the Cross, Master Eckhart and Hildegard of Bingen, provide detailed accounts of their experiences which closely resemble mine in form, content and resolution.

I was shocked to hear Senator Parer use intimate revelations about my spiritual journey in an attempt to undermine my credibility as a commentator on climate change policy. I have been critical of the Government's economic arguments about the impact of measures to reduce greenhouse gases for some time. At no stage has Senator Parer responded to my arguments or the evidence I have adduced. Now he has used Question Time in the Senate to launch a pre‐meditated personal attack on me by way of my religious experience.

My credentials as a commentator on climate change policy have not been questioned by anyone, but in case any observer should have doubts after Senator Parer's attack I would like to record the following. I hold a degree in Pure Mathematics from the Australian National University and a First Class Honours degree in Economics from the University of Sydney. I was offered a doctoral place at Cambridge University but chose to take my doctorate at the University of Sussex. My thesis was a general equilibrium model of development and was published internationally. I was subsequently employed as a Research Fellow at the Australian National University and served as the Director of the Graduate Program in the Economics of Development. I joined the Commonwealth Public Service in 1987 and was appointed to the Senior Executive Service in 1989.

In addition to my role as Executive Director of the Australia Institute, I am a Visiting Fellow in Public Policy at the Australian National University and an Adjunct Professor at the University of Technology, Sydney. I have served on a United Nations Expert Group on Least Developed Countries and have frequently been asked to present papers at conferences and seminars in Australia and abroad. I have been a senior adviser to the Government of Indonesia, employed by the US Government.

I have published widely, including four books and many articles in Australian and international refereed academic journals. Several of these articles have been written jointly with some of Australia's most respected academic economists. Three of Australia's most eminent academic economists—Professor Peter Dixon of Monash University, Professor Tor Hundloe of the University of Queensland and Professor John Quiggin of James Cook University—joined with me in preparing a statement on climate change that challenged the Government's arguments, a statement that was signed by 131 professional Australian economists.

I have been employed to carry out research into climate change policy by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, the Department of Environment Sport and Territories, the Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering, and the Sustainable Energy Development Authority.

Finally, I take offence at Senator Parer's reference to me as `anti‐Australian'. I am very proud of being an Australian. I founded The Australia Institute—an independent non‐profit research centre—in order to help make Australia a more just, sustainable and peaceful country. I believe that the Government's present climate change policy will cause serious damage to Australia's short‐term and long‐term interests, and find it disturbing that those who disagree with the Government are branded `anti‐Australian'.
Clive Hamilton
29th September 1997

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The 1997‐98 Budget demonstrates the Federal Government's continuing commitment to caring for Australia's veterans and their families. As well as initiatives to assist them live the independent lives of their choice, the opportunity has been taken to streamline administration and remove anomalies in entitlements.

The 1997‐98 Budget continued the Government's four‐year commemorative program, Their Service‐Our Heritage , which will encourage all Australians to remember the sacrifice and service of our veterans across the years. Commemorating the service rendered by men and women in uniform has become an integral part of Australia's way of life.

Of course, remembering the fallen is not enough; we must also continue to look after the living. This bill will give legislative effect to a Budget initiative to extend eligibility for disability pension and access to Repatriation health care arrangements to an additional 10,500 veterans. Some veterans will also benefit by gaining eligibility for the service pension and Defence Service Homes loans.

This initiative arises out of a recent review of perceived anomalies in eligibility for veterans' entitlements for overseas deployments since World War 2. This review was foreshadowed in the Government's election policy statement, Lest We Forget. The review sought fairness and consistency in applying the longstanding principles underlying access to Repatriation benefits.

Eligibility for disability pension and benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 will now be available to veterans who had seagoing Naval service with the Far East Strategic Reserve between 1955 and 1963, to veterans who served in North East Thailand between 1962 and 1968, and to veterans who served in Japan with the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces between 1949 and 1951. Eligibility for disability pensions will also be extended to veterans who served in various other overseas deployments in the post‐war years. Qualifying service for service pension will be extended to Embassy Guards and RAAF personnel who served in Vietnam between 1973 and 1975.

An important change in this bill is the automatic extension of eligibility for Repatriation benefits to veterans for any overseas operational service determined to be warlike or non‐warlike by the Minister for Defence. These are classifications now used by the Department of Defence to cover operations of higher risk than normal peace‐time service. The inclusion of these classifications of service will give veterans greater certainty about their eligibility under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 before they commence future overseas deployments. In addition, these classifications should minimise the potential for anomalies to occur in the future.

Another 1997‐98 Budget initiative in this bill will allow all disability pensioners, war widow and war widower pensioners access to a lump sum advance of their pension, up to a maximum of $500 a year. Previously, this advance has been available to income support pensioners only. These changes recognise the benefit of allowing people with continuing Commonwealth pensions greater flexibility and choice as to how they access their pension payments.

This bill also introduces a reform to the Repatriation system that reflects a greater public awareness of the medical consequences of tobacco use and the current initiatives to discourage smoking within the general community and also within the Defence Forces. If, in the past, veterans did not know the dangers of smoking, or if they were encouraged to use tobacco, this is certainly not true for veterans today.

The Commonwealth will no longer be liable for compensation for the medical consequences of smoking tobacco if the person takes up the habit after 31 December 1997, or if the consequences are due to an increase in smoking after 31 December 1997.

This measure will not affect veterans who acquired a service related smoking habit before 1 January 1998, unless the medical consequences are due only to a later increase in tobacco use. However, let me stress that if smoking is only one of the causal factors in the development of a condition, then there will still be eligibility for compensation for the incapacity or death if other, service‐related factors exist.

Another 1997‐98 Budget initiative in this bill streamlines the determination of a service pensioner's eligibility for medical treatment at the expense of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. As a result of this simplification and the associated removal of anomalies, about 100 veterans will gain access to treatment benefits.
This bill also includes a number of initiatives the Government announced as part of its 1996‐97 Budget.

One of these initiatives is the rationalisation of the administration and payment of pensions between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security. This reflects the Government's commitment to administrative reform to streamline the delivery of Government services.

The bill will allow age pensioners, who also receive a veteran's disability pension, to choose to be paid both pensions by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. For the veterans, and their eligible partners, it will mean that they need deal with only one Department. Veterans will have the choice whether to use this agency arrangement. It is a popular option with over 10,000 veterans already asking the Department of Veterans' Affairs to manage all payments.

The bill also provides for all carer payments to be managed by the Department of Social Security. Most of the carer payments made by the Department of Veterans' Affairs will be transferred to Social Security. A few carer payments will remain with Veterans' Affairs to either preserve their carer payment which is at a rate higher than they would otherwise receive from Social Security, or avoid the inconvenience of the carer having to reapply to the Department of Veterans' Affairs when they become eligible for another form of income support payment.
Another 1996‐97 Budget initiative in this bill will establish a Vocational Rehabilitation Scheme for veterans.
This Government undertook to closely monitor the long term care needs of Vietnam veterans and this measure has been long awaited by the Vietnam veteran community.
The Scheme will provide for early intervention for younger veterans leaving the Forces and support for Vietnam veterans. It will assist veterans to find employment and to continue in employment.

The development of the legislation for the Scheme, and of the Scheme itself, has been the subject of extensive consultation with the ex‐service community. Thanks go to the veteran community for their assistance in developing this Scheme.

The Scheme will be available to all eligible veterans, but special provision has been made for those veterans who are receiving a disability pension or a service pension on the grounds that they are prevented by their incapacity from working full‐time. The legislation presented guarantees veterans who volunteer to take part in a rehabilitation program under the Scheme will not have their disability pension reduced while participating in that program.

The legislation ensures the veteran will receive at least the same income, from earnings and disability pension combined, as he or she would have re ceived as a disability pensioner had the veteran not participated in the
rehabilitation program and entered employment.
If, at any time, the veteran ceases employment he or she will revert to the rate of disability pension payable when the rehabilitation program was initially undertaken

These safeguards and guarantees remove disincentives for veterans to volunteer for rehabilitation back into the workforce. The benefits veterans may obtain from participating in a rehabilitation program go beyond the financial advantages. These programs increase a person's self reliance and ability to cope with life's tasks, provide opportunities for socialisation, and can help improve the quality of the participant's life.

Before concluding, I want to say the Government is making significant improvements to the way the functions of the Department of Veterans' Affairs are managed and delivered. This includes the selective outsourcing of functions where the private sector can deliver quality service at a price that the public sector cannot match. The Department of Veterans' Affairs has been very innovative in this area, as evidenced by its extensive health and hospital service purchasing, and more recently, by the outsourcing of its computer infrastructure. This was a first for the Commonwealth public service. It will mean better service for the veteran community and better value for the taxpayer's dollar.
Taken as a whole, the measures in this bill will result in better policy, more efficient administration and, most importantly, a better quality of life for the veteran community.
Madam President, I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Workplace Relations Amendment Bill is one of the most blatant pieces of political propaganda to be put before the Senate in the last 18 months. It is nothing more than a con. It is a stunt and it is an act of utter desperation by what has increasingly become a desperate government. It is a con with regard to the small business community. All this government is really interested in is media headlines. This legislation will not help small business. Once again, this legislation is all about the government trying to make people believe that it is actually doing something.

SPEECH.PARA: When talking about make believe, it is also interesting to note the lengths that this government has gone to to try and con the Australian public into believing that this bill is making changes to Labor legislation with regard to unfair dismissal. This is not the case. This government is actually attempting to change its own legislation—legislation which, incidentally, has been in operation for only nine months. I think it is very important to get that on the record because, if you believe the spin by Mr Reith, you would think that this legislation is about amending the now opposition's old unfair dismissal laws.

The exemption is inherently unfair, it is inherently unnecessary and it is a breach of the government's pre-election commitments. This will come as no surprise to people in this chamber and as no surprise to people in the Australian community. This government declared again and again that there would not be any exemption for small business from the unfair dismissal provisions. As clearly documented in the minority report of the opposi tion and the Democrats, both John Howard and Peter Reith—with hand on heart, saying, `Trust me, I am from the government'—declared that this exemption would not happen.
Let us have a look at a bit of history with regard to the government's pre-election commitments on this. On the John Laws show on 23 January 1996, John Howard stated:
. . . I'm not going to have a law where an unreasonable employer can capriciously sack a decent, hard‐working employee.
That is the first thing he said. Let us have a look at what Peter Reith said. On ABC Daybreak , 28 February 1996, he stated quite succinctly:
Look, our position's very clear. If you've been unfairly dealt with at work, then you should have a right of appeal.
There is not much leeway there. Both John Howard and Peter Reith have been absolutely clear, quite consistently, that there will not be an exemption contemplated by this government.

History moves on. John Howard and Peter Reith then went on to give themselves a big pat on the back when commenting on the new Workplace Relations Act. In his speech on the return of the bill from the Senate on 21 November 1996, Peter Reith said:

We have delivered a workable system for dealing with unfair dismissal on the basis of a fair go all round and, in doing so, we have expressed an overwhelming community consensus that the previous . . . system did nothing more than stifle employment growth and create division in the workplace. This was Labor's legacy, and the government has buried it.
John Howard then stated—

—In his 1996 progress report to the people on 11 December 1996, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to say that the previous government's . . . unfair dismissal laws have gone. They have been replaced with a simpler, more balanced system that provides a fair go all round.

This is a comment on legislation that the government is seeking to amend here today. Unfortunately, for a large number of employees, this government has once again shown that it cannot be trusted. It does not stick to its word. What this bill seeks to do is to take unfair dismissal rights away from Australians who are employed in a business with 15 or fewer employees, except for apprentices. For these workers—we are talking about one-third of the Australian work force—there will be no right of appeal, no justice and no equality under the law. So much for the comments of Mr Reith and Mr Howard!

It seeks to take away rights from Australians so that they are no longer protected from harsh, unfair and unreasonable dismissal. Nobody could call that an Australian activity. It is not what the Australian community is about. Australian workers and Australian small business do not support it, and I will go on to explain why.

The government is on very shaky ground indeed with regard to this legislation, and the government knows it. This government wants to give employers the right to sack workers unfairly. There is no other way that it can be construed. The current unfair dismissal provisions apply to all employers irrespective of size. There are, however, some exemptions to these provisions, which include employees serving a probationary period provided that the period was determined in advance.
The majority report from the government presented to the Senate on Monday offers no legitimate reasons as to why this should be changed. The government states in its report:
. . . the current legislation was `too legalistic and too prescriptive' and therefore providing Government with the motive for change.

The current legislation provides that employees cannot be terminated for reasons that are harsh, unjust or unreasonable. What part of that is too legalistic? The legislation is clear. Australians understand what the legislation means. Small businesses understand what the legislation means. I totally agree with Senator Murray's comments in his report where he states:
The Report of the Coalition is analytically weak and is not persuasive.
That is the understatement of the decade. He also states:
What we are dealing with is a perception manufactured by the Coalition, that their unfair dismissal laws inhibit job creation in small business. The reality is that those new laws do not.
He also states:
The Coalition has deliberately and cynically tried to create a statistical no-go area. It has indulged in statistical subterfuge.

This subterfuge is all too evident to people who attended the hearings of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee given the fact that, as we discovered yesterday, the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business in its own survey gave small business the option of naming the unfair dismissal provisions as the reason for not increasing employment. When the department rang small business, it asked, `Are the unfair dismissal provisions a disincentive?' This was under the old legislation, not the government's legislation. But small business did not and they did not cite it as a reason. It was not even mentioned. So the department did not include it in its report because it rated so low. It was very conveniently omitted.
I think Senator Murray hit the nail on the head when he cites in his report the reason for the subterfuge. He quite frankly says—and I think he is absolutely correct:

It remains my belief that the Coalition introduced this single-issue Bill encapsulating gross unfairness, to provoke the Senate to absolute rejection. It remains my belief that this Bill was conceived to achieve a double-dissolution trigger.
Spot on, Senator Murray; that is absolutely correct. The small business community certainly do not want the exemption, they do not need it and they did not ask for it. That is the reality.

Let us have a look at why this is before us. I think Senator Murray has quite accurately described the double dissolution trigger aspect and the very weak response by the government in its is majority report as to the requirement for this legislation. Let us have a look at what is going on in the Liberal Party at the moment.

We had the somewhat unedifying sight of the Treasurer, Mr Costello, in his address to the MTIA last night basically trumpeting the fact that he had won in cabinet with regard to spiking a more strategic interventionist approach to the economy versus what the MTIA and the majority of industry want, which is a more interventionist approach—that is, assistance, encouragement and a reason for the government to play a bigger role with regard to economic development industry policy.

In term of the MTIA's seven statements as to why it believes that its case should have been taken up by the government, Mr Costello did not get past the first two. So he has clearly won! What we have within the Liberal Party is a call for further reform with regard to industrial relations. That was very adequately described by Senator Vanstone, who let the cat out of the bag when she said, `What we need, as it were, is less job security.' That is what certain sections of the Liberal Party are about.

What this is really about—and I think everybody knows it—is internal divisions within the Liberal Party and who is going to be the next leader of the Liberal Party. Will it be Mr Reith or will it be Mr Costello?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Cheryl Kernot!
—Leader of the Liberal Party?
—You never know.

—I do not think Mr Reith has the numbers. So what we have here in Mr Reith's behaviour are increasingly desperate moves to deal him back into the leadership stakes. Peter Costello is positioning himself for a move. That has been publicly speculated so it will come as no surprise to people in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the empirical evidence as to why this legislation is not necessary. I will quote here from the minority report prepared by the Labor Party members and Senator Murray from the Democrats. The Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business produced the following evidence to the Senate committee:

. . . there has been a significant decrease in the number of applications made under the federal unfair dismissal legislation. In the first 37 weeks of 1996 there were 10,408 applications under the then Industrial Relations Act 1988; in the first 37 weeks of 1997 . . . there were 4,801 applications under the Workplace Relations Act—that is, a decrease by 54%—

and this relates to all unfair dismissal claims. So under the government's new legislation, which was much vaunted by the government, there was a 54 per cent decrease with regard to unfair dismissal claims. You would have thought that that would have been fairly adequate, but no. The report continues:

. . . statistics from the 1995/96 Industrial Relations Court Annual Report show that . . . perhaps contrary to popular misconception, small business has fewer unfair dismissal claims than other employers: only a third of [unfair dismissal claims] is from the small business sector notwithstanding that 91.7% of employers have fewer than 20 employees.
Pretty persuasive stuff I would have thought. Our report concludes:
. . . less than 1 in every 100 involuntary dismissals in small business are now affected by federal unfair dismissal claims.

Claims and applications since the government's unfair dismissal laws came into operation have been dramatically reduced—that is, claims against all business, not just against small business. I refer the chamber to page 21 of our report with regard to that.

Why is this happening? We have already cited the reason of internal divisions within the Liberal Party, but let us have a look at the economy. This bill is the political equivalent of kicking the cat. When you have got nothing else to do, when the economy is flatlining, when unemployment is going up and when economic growth is flatlining, what do you do? Let us imagine the discussion around the cabinet room, `I know. Let's bring in a bill to exempt small business from unfair dismissal. That is at least a bit of a symbol or a sign that we are attempting to do something because we can't get the economic fundamentals right.' That is the reality.

The government's central premise with regard to this legislation is that their own unfair dismissal laws provide a disincentive to employment. Despite the changed unfair dismissal laws, employment has not increased under this government. I know senators on the other side of the chamber do not like hearing this but let us revisit the figures since the government came to office.

Unemployment is currently running at 8.6 per cent. When the government came into power it was running at 8.4 per cent. You do not have to be Einstein to work out there is clearly a huge unemployment problem that this government, by its actions, has not addressed. The participation rate is again stagnant at 63 per cent. The number of long-term unemployed has grown by 70,000 in the past year to 411,000. Those statistics were from the Australian on Friday. Our foreign debt—something that does not get much of a run these days—has risen above $220 billion, up 2.2 per cent on the previous quarter. Peter Costello said that Australia would grow by four per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Mackay, you must refer to people by their proper title.
—Sorry, Mr Costello—is that adequate?
—That is adequate.

—We are not on familiar terms anyway. Mr Costello has said that Australia would grow by four per cent. That is the government's objective and that is what Mr Howard said in his headland speech prior to the election. What have we got? At the end of the June quarter, we left the last financial year with a growth rate of 2.5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The job creation figure of 75,000 jobs is effectively only one per cent seasonally adjusted. That is extremely weak employment growth for a whole year—pathetically weak, I would venture to suggest. The government has made much of the growth of 16 per cent in private sector investment outcomes. That is true, but most of that investment—if you disaggregate and examine those figures—was already in place when this government came in. In any event, even if the government were to claim some kind of a pyrrhic victory with regard to that private sector growth, it has not created any jobs—no jobs. The 1997-98 business expectation figures are as flat as a pancake. New capital expenditure is $39.46 billion for 1996-97. The whole economy is stagnant and economic growth is flatline—no growth.

This government believes that their own unfair dismissal laws are a significant deterrent to small business employing more people. Let us have a look at what the government cited as empirical evidence to sustain this claim. They quoted the employment survey by Morgan and Banks. However, they did not mention that this survey shows that 78.9 per cent of small businesses were not affected by the laws in their decisions to hire new staff. They also failed to note that only 2.7 per cent said the laws meant they had hired significantly fewer employees. This survey was carried out before the government's amendments to the then unfair dismissals laws.

The government also cited the Recruitment Solutions survey. This survey is severely in doubt because it is completely out of line with statistics provided by the ABS, the IRC and DIR. In the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, or TCCI, survey, unfair dismissals were ranked 11th out of 58 business issues. The government said: `This is a very severe problem that Tasmanian business believe unfair dismissal is 11th out of 58 variables with regard to being a disincentive to creating employment.' When you have a look at what the first 10 issues were, they included such things as parliamentary reform. But, most importantly, what it revealed was the fact that the demand was not there. The problem is that the demand is not there in the economy to employ people, and it is not going to magically appear by removing the unfair dismissal provisions. Life, unfortunately, is not like that. But that is the reality. The government cited that TCCI survey as well.

It is interesting to note that ACCI were the only employer group to front the committee. Quite frankly, they provided quite spurious evidence, which I understand Senator Jacinta Collins will expand on later. ACCI's assertions were simply not backed up with any empirical evidence. In terms of the submission ACCI provided to the legislation committee, I guess you have to wonder whom they have been talking to and, more appositely, what group they think they represent. The department itself referred selectively to survey evidence, but it actually failed to refer to its own far more credible survey even though its survey specifically addressed the question of unfair dismissals.

We then go to the Yellow Pages survey. We are trawling around here to try to find some reason as to why the government wants to introduce this legislation, some actual hard empirical data. The May Yellow Pages survey clearly showed that of those businesses surveyed 37 per cent believed barriers existed to investment expenditure. In the responses, 32 per cent indicated cash flow, 23 per cent indicated lack of work, 19 per cent indicated profitability and nine per cent indicated the economic climate as reasons. Only three per cent indicated cost of employing staff—we are assuming this may include the unfair dismissal laws—as a barrier to investment expenditure. It is obvious that small business simply do not regard the government's unfair dismissal laws as a disincentive.

In the August Yellow Pages survey, businesses were asked: `What are the barriers to taking on new employees?' Not surprisingly, lack of work was the overwhelming response with 42 per cent. Significantly, on an unprompted response, the unfair dismissal laws did not even rate a mention. As I said, it just makes you wonder who the government is talking to and who ACCI is talking to.

To conclude, we oppose this legislation. At a time when job security is probably the most important issue for Australian workers, we believe that it is completely unfair to deprive one‐third of Australian employees from having that recourse. The small business community do not want it, they do not need it and they did not ask for it. This has the potential to encourage worst practice—not best practice—from unscrupulous employers who will be given the right to hire and fire at will.

This exemption will clearly add to job insecurity difficulties. The bottom line is that this exemption has the potential to lead to anarchy and turmoil in the workplace. It will not assist with employment; it will not assist with improving the growth of the economy. It just will not help. It is just a cheap political stunt and a few good headlines for Mr Reith—which I suspect he needs at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 is the second attempt by this government to impose its ill‐considered and discriminatory proposal to exempt businesses employing no more than 15 workers from the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996. In late June 1997, the Senate voted to disallow regulations under the act which have the same intent as the bill before us today. At that time, I voted for the disallowance and I see no need to change my position.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in the debate on the Workplace Relations Bill in November 1996, the unfair dismissal provisions, as they existed at the time of that debate, had not been given a proper chance to be evaluated. It is interesting to note in the committee report on this bill that Senator Murray had used a similar argument in relation to the new unfair dismissal regime that took effect after the proclamation of the Workplace Relations Act 1996.

Whilst I am pleased to see that he and the Australian Democrats will not be supporting this bill and its further diminution of workers' rights in relation to unfair dismissal, I wish that he—and to some extent the ALP—had listened to the likes of Justice Murray Wilcox, whom I quoted in the debate on the unfair dismissal provisions in the 1996 act. He argued that his contact with business groups indicated to him that the pre Workplace Relations Act provisions in relation to unfair dismissals were `working very smoothly'.

I believe that many people have been hoodwinked into believing that there is a massive problem with unfair dismissal and that business, especially small business, is being hamstrung by unworkable regulations with respect to the dismissal of their employees.

I believe that what is not being taken into consideration is the major issues affecting small business, that is, getting people through their door. That relates to people's level of spendable income, their discretionary income—that is, that level of income above what they need for their absolute necessities such as housing, rent and food, that amount that they can spend on goods and services. Many of these people are from small businesses.

A very large factor in people's spending patterns is whether they think they are going to be employed this week, next week or next month. So people's certainty or uncertainty about their job security is a very large factor in whether they support small business, or whether they support large business, whether they are able to spend any discretionary income that they have.

The government has a very reductionist way of thinking. They think that whatever seems to be good for an individual small business—trying to make your employees as vulnerable as possible, keeping down wages and conditions and so on—is necessarily going to be good for the whole small business sector.

I would like people to go back and at least read some of the issues that were brought up from the 1930s, in particular some of the work of John Maynard Keynes. He was not actually radical, but he did say—and it is a very important point—that what is good for one part of the economy is not necessarily good for the whole economy.

Of course, the whole `greed is good' phenomenon was about people spending more money so that big businesses made a lot of money. We have a society that is based on a greed principle. That is what the market is all about. People will spend—that is fine; that is what that principle is about. But we are extrapolating what appears to be what an individual small business might want—that is, to keep their costs down to a minimum, to be able to have the maximum flexibility with their particular employees—and we assume that putting that out to the whole economy is going to be good for the economy. Clearly, it is not. And that does not appear to be the major issue for small business and many other businesses in Australia. It is about the industrial structure; it is about the way communities are operating and the way the economy is performing.

In many instances, it can be about whether there is a range of industries within an area, so that they are not dependent on one major industry which might have problems and then create pressure for all the rest. There are a whole lot of issues. I believe that trying to pretend to small business that you are doing something about their concerns is a very simplistic and erroneous way to deal with the situation.

If the need to sack an employee does arise, the employee is entitled to basic procedural fairness. I do not think that is unreasonable. The government's claims that this initiative will promote employment is laughable. The committee report on this bill by Senator Ferguson, on behalf of the government, states:

It is widely regarded that regulation in the labour market is an obstacle for employment growth, particularly in relation to small business. The more labour regulation, the less incentives are given to business to employ higher volumes of staff.

This faith in deregulation is totally misplaced. As I have mentioned before, it will create substantially greater uncertainty in the community and, ironically, it will mostly be small businesses that will suffer as consumer confidence plummets.

In summary, the Greens believe that the pre Workplace Relations Act provisions were reasonable and had not had a reasonable time to be evaluated. The 1996 act further eroded workers' rights, and this bill proposes to minimise the protections for specific categories of workers. Whilst I acknowledge that these changes relate to unfair as opposed to unlawful dismissal and that they apply only to workers employed in small businesses with no more than 15 permanent employees, who are covered under the federal act, I do not see the need for any category of worker to be treated in an unfair manner and be exempted from these basic protections. Therefore, we will not be supporting this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson. I presume you are going to be dispassionate and objective whilst you are in the chair, as the signatory to the majority report by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. As always, the secretariat did a good job, because the three reports present ed cover the range of views that were required to be covered.

SPEECH.PARA: Most importantly, the very way in which the secretariat wrote their report indicated their lack of real professional support, if you like, for an absolutely insupportable argument. They could not find the evidence. That secretariat—for whom I have the highest regard, as I know all senators do—damned you with the very faint ability they could bring to your particular report, simply because the evidence and the arguments were not there.

I get somewhat distressed when I encounter in this sort of situation a minister for whom I have the highest professional regard, and I refer to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). He is a minister whose professional experience, seniority and understanding of the political process in both houses and whose ability to manage his portfolios are quite exceptional within the government and the range of talent they have within their front bench. Yet, this is a minister who has broken an agreement with me and my party in introducing this and who, I believe, has indulged in statistical subterfuge to arrive at a position which is not justified by the facts and which is not justified by anything other than cruel and heartless politics.

I do not really mind the minister playing hard ball with Labor or the Democrats on political issues and the business of muscling through policies, philosophies, ideologies and perspectives. I do mind when the issue that comes to mind is that of treating workers unfairly, of allowing 1.6 million workers—one‐quarter of the work force—to feel that their very job security and the very rights that are available to the rest of the work force will be denied them.

When you take such a position, if you are going to take such a position, you can only ever do so in the belief that the greater good—the greater public interest available to our community—will be served and that the evil that will be done will be less, much less, than the good that will be done. That is why I began this address by referring to the lack of evidence to support that proposition. The Labor Party report very ably rebutted that proposition.

I remind the Senate that, under the Brereton laws—the previous minister's labour laws—the growth rate in employment generation in small business was double that of large business. So, even in those days, the proposition that there was major job restriction consequences to those laws was on somewhat shaky empirical grounds. But now that the new laws actually have cut unfair dismissal applications by 52 per cent—let us repeat that, it is half: from 15,000‐odd to just over 6,000 out of over eight million employees—you have to worry and wonder why the government has introduced this bill.

I have made the point in my minority report that I believe that, whereas in the early days they put up the regulation which the Senate rejected—and it may have been provoked by the somewhat macho contest between the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the minister, who is the heir apparent—this particular bill has been introduced with the knowledge that the Senate, in its wisdom, would find it repugnant and would reject it. It is a single issue bill, and it would give them a double dissolution trigger. Whether they use it or not, every government likes to have such a thing.

Speaking for myself and my party, I do not mind giving you a double dissolution trigger if it means rejecting a bill which delivers gross unfairness and gross insecurity to the workers who are at the most vulnerable end of our community. Incidentally, according to the union representation in the committees, only a very minor percentage of workers are unionised in retail—I think they gave the figure of some two per cent. It is the job of the government to look after the weak and vulnerable. It is the job of the government, if it says it represents battlers, to be concerned about those battlers. They are not union hacks; they are people who are not represented by organised labour.

I say, and I believe many people say, that this exemption—this right to sack workers unfairly—for small businesses with fewer than 15 members will create job insecurity and not jobs. No evidence of any substance was presented to the committee, and nor has any been presented whilst this issue has been available over many years, to prove that doing this will result in job creation. That is the first thing we reject.

The second aspect we reject is that the new laws are inadequate. I am aware that many Labor Party senators and unionists think that the new laws go too far. The fact is that they deliver, in our view, the minimum level of equity and natural justice required to protect a worker from being harshly, unjustly or unfairly dismissed. The numbers are not enormous. Federally, the numbers will be around 6,000 cases.

If federal unfair dismissal applications are down 52 per cent, we should ask the government, `What were you trying to achieve when you put in your new laws? Surely, this would be a target that you would find acceptable to yourselves.' If I said to somebody that the result of my law was that I could grow something by 52 per cent or decrease something by 52 per cent, I would be immensely proud of the achievement. But my belief is that the federal unfair dismissal applications being down 52 per cent is a massive recognition of the success and the applicability of those laws.

Now we come to what is, for me, the real killer. To find out what lies underneath the assertion that unfair dismissals impede job growth and are, in fact, unfair to small business, we have attempted—and I have attempted—for over a year now to discover what the real statistical situation is. When I began my remarks I commented that the government has indulged in statistical subterfuge. I think that is so. It chose a number—15 employees—below which this exemption will apply; yet the ABS number is 20. The consequence is that it is virtually impossible for the committee or any interest group, either on the employer or the employee side, or for the Senate, to establish the real number of small businesses that will be affected and the real number of employees who will be affected. That is why we are forced to rely on assumptions.

But there is much more to it than that. The industrial registries within the Industrial Relations Commission and in the Federal Court do not record the size of the businesses that come before them. So it is very natural to say to the government, `If the intention is just to exempt small businesses below the number of 15 employees, could you please let us know how many of those small businesses there actually are?' They say, `Oh no, we can't afford to do that; we don't have the time and the resources to do that.' Why? Because you do not want the truth to come out.

It is very plain to us that you have attempted to conceal the fact that the majority of unfair dismissal applications are against big business, not small business. This bill of yours is a stalking horse for big business. It is an attempt to do away with a minimum protection which is available for workers who might otherwise be sacked unfairly. Anyone in the Senate who, at some stage in their life, has been either the victim or the potential victim of someone with supreme power over you, because you need the job and you have to take what they give you, will know how utterly unfair it is if you do not have recourse to some means of complaint, if it is required.

How many people are going to complain under the federal unfair dismissal laws this year? The estimate is 6,700. Why do we want to punish 6,700 people in this giant country of ours? It does not affect small business primarily; it affects big business, so it is just a furphy.

If we look deeper into the statistics we discover that the 52 per cent of reductions in unfair dismissals are drastically reduced when you lump federal, state and territory jurisdictions together. Where employees have a chance to come under either the federal law or the state law, they will use whichever jurisdiction is better for them. They go to the state jurisdiction in a number of states. The consequence is that the overall decrease—when you add together state, territory and federal decreases—is about 27 per cent.

We have to then ask: what would happen if you took the states out of the equation? In Victoria, the ACT and the Northern Territory, the decline in unfair dismissal applications where only one jurisdiction applies, which is the federal jurisdiction, is one‐third. I will say to you that a one‐third reduction is an enormous achievement if that was the govern ment's intention in introducing the unfair dismissal laws.

When you look at the states you find that New South Wales is down only 18 per cent; South Australia has not moved but is the same; WA is down 24 per cent; and Tasmania has increased by 12 per cent. I say to the coalition, if there is an unfair dismissal applications problem which is being expressed in surveys—which, by the way, do not express the difference between federal and state laws—it is in the states. Yet you want to introduce a federal law change which discriminates unfairly against workers because there is a states problem. So this is exposed once again as a cruel, heartless and immensely political exercise.

The next point we need to make is that our laws require that we do not discriminate against people unfairly. It has been a basic principle of justice from the time of Moses that people are equal before the law. How can you have a law which applies to three‐quarters of employees and not to one‐quarter? How can you allow the most weak and vulnerable sector in our employment spectrum not to have the protection of law against harsh, unjust or unfair dismissal?

I am dismayed that this government would even conceive of a breach of such a fundamental principle. Let me repeat that you can only breach fundamental principles like that if the public good far exceeds the public evil that you have done by it. It does not in this case. You will not deliver more jobs as a result of your bill. You will not improve the lot of employers as a result of this bill. You will not improve the lot of employees as a result of this bill. You certainly will not do anything about the state laws, which is where the real problem resides. That is the coalition perspective.

From the Labor perspective, they say that there is no problem in that regard. By and large, I think Labor's view is that the state jurisdictions look pretty fair to them. I would expect that that would be Labor's view in South Australia and New South Wales. I do not know how they feel about Western Australia, Queensland and the other states, but I am sure they will speak for themselves and let me know how they feel about those. I would expect that that would be the argument from an opposition perspective.

I am deeply concerned that the coalition should see fit to put employees at risk and should see fit to be prepared to sack workers unfairly. Some 1.6 million workers could potentially be sacked unfairly because you want a double‐ dissolution trigger. I expect the Senate to reject this bill. I expect in the House of Representatives that you will come bustling back and say, `We want our way.' The Senate must, in my view, reject this bill.

We will continue to argue and expose your perfidy in terms of the facts and the statistics. You are not going to get away with it. We will find out what is in those industrial registers. We will find out the facts. We will let the nation know that you have lied, that you have said that this is about small business when it is about large business and that you said that you had an agreement with the Australian Democrats when you broke that agreement with me. I did not agree at any time, my former leader did not agree at any time, the Australian Democrats did not agree at any time to allow workers to be sacked unfairly. We will never agree to that whichever party is in power.

This bill is just not right. It is not appropriate. It does not deliver jobs. It is not good justice. It is not factually supported. It has no basis in economics, in social and judicial policy and in any other area. It is founded entirely on the hard and nasty rocks of political expediency. I dislike it intensely for that reason. I am deeply distressed that a minister of the seniority, experience, background and understanding of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business should be the proponent and supporter of such a bill. I therefore advise that I will be moving to reject the bill on the second reading. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comments in this debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 . The appropriate place to commence is by referring to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996. That amending act that was proclaimed to apply from 1 January this year is relatively straightforward in its application. It outlines certain grounds in which an employer must not terminate an employee's employment. Essentially, it says that employers must not dismiss an employee for reasons not connected with either the performance of the employee or the organisational requirements of the enterprise, and that reason must not be harsh, unjust or unreasonable. As it currently applies, the act applies equally to all employees regardless of their award status.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of observations should be made about the current act before we discuss the amending bill. Firstly, it applies to all employees regardless of their award status. Hence, it does not discriminate between workers, genders or the size of the business.

Secondly, and quite importantly, it has a conceptual underpinning quite consistent with traditional Australian ethos. Essentially it says that if you perform the work required by your employer, the law will not permit that employer to behave in an arbitrary, capricious or discriminatory fashion by terminating your employment. It means that work is important and that continued employment is valued. It means that so important is the nature of work that the statute law overrules the common law, firstly, by restricting the right of employers to dismiss employees and, secondly, by saying that any dismissal shall not be discriminatory or unfair.

BREAK.PARA: Thirdly, the act provides all employees with the opportunity for an independent tribunal to review what that employee might believe to be an unfair dismissal. Again, it is with the provision that the current act reinforces the notion of equality before the law, and adds a significant degree of egalitarianism in practice by saying that all employees can avail themselves of taxpayer funded, state supported conciliation and, if necessary, arbitration of potentially unfair dismissal laws.

Fourthly, by any stretch of the imagination, it can be said that from the government's point of view the provisions of the current act have been greatly successful. The current act has been in place for only nine months. Table 1 of the majority report discloses that the number of applications lodged with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on an annualised basis have fallen from 14,028 in 1996 to 6,700 in 1997. In 1996 there were 14,028 applications and this year the number of applications to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission seeking reinstatement has decreased to 6,700. That is a huge drop in the number of persons seeking to test a dismissal by an employer in the Industrial Relations Commission. In excess of 7,300 fewer cases are the subject of application to the Industrial Relations Commission during the same period in the years 1996 and 1997.

In summary, we know that fewer employees are using the current act. Consequently, we can accurately conclude that very few small businesses are in any way affected by the current provisions of the act. It follows logically that a maximum of 6,700 of the 353,000 small businesses in Australia that actually employ labour will derive any benefit from the proposed amending bill. In stark terms, .018 per cent of all small businesses in Australia that employ people stand to enjoy any impact, let alone gain any advantage, if this bill is passed. That is, 99.98 per cent of all small businesses in Australia that employ persons are not affected by the current act, and will not be affected by the amending bill.

For example, in my own state of Western Australia, fewer than 600 small businesses employing people have been affected by the act. One large shopping centre the size of Booragoon or Morley has more than 600 firms employing labour. That is how small, minor and insignificant the impact of the bill will be if it is passed by the Senate. With that background and understanding of the current act, I will now turn to the amending bill.

The bill, as stated in the majority report, will have this effect. Any employee who is first engaged by the relevant employer after the commencement of the bill will not be able to make an application on the ground that the termination of his or her employment was harsh, unjust or unreasonable where he or she was employed by an employer who employs fewer than 15 employees. Put simply, new employees of an employer employing fewer than 15 workers cannot use the unfair dismissal provisions. So the amending bill discriminates, firstly, between existing and future employees, secondly, between firms employing more than 15 employees and fewer than 15 employees in the future and, thirdly, different sizes of employers who regard themselves as coming within that category of small business, however defined.

If we look at the report of the government senators, the arguments in favour of this discriminatory approach to employees essentially boil down to two: small business needs protection from oppressive industrial relations legislation and the bill, if passed, will aid employment growth. Let us look now at each of these arguments in turn and put on the public record some of the evidence presented to the committee. We know the following from submissions provided by the departments and latterly from responses to supplementary questions put in writing to relevant officers of the department.

Firstly, there are 780,000 small businesses in Australia. Secondly, there are 353,000 small businesses in Australia which employ labour. Thirdly, in the period 31 December 1996 to 12 September 1997 there were 4,800 applications made to the Industrial Relations Commission. Those 4,800 applications included all businesses, large, medium and small. Fourthly, of those 4,800 applications, 2,807 in total were settled prior to arbitration. Almost 60 per cent—the exact figure being 58.46 per cent—of all applications to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission were settled prior to arbitration. The figure of 2,807 comprises the following: 121 were finalised for a preliminary reason; 679 were withdrawn or discontinued; 1,663 were settled by conciliation; and 344 were settled after conciliation but prior to arbitration.

In summary, of the 4,800 applications, 2,807, or almost 60 per cent, were settled in a one‐ or two‐hour conference engaged in before a conciliation commissioner. A further 1,675 are still awaiting conciliation. Of the 4,800 applications, the lousy figure of 56 matters were resolved by arbitration and another 239 are awaiting arbitration some time in the future. The question arises: what statistical conclusion can be drawn from this evidence provided in table 4 in response to supplementary questions asked by me in writing to the department?

Of the 350,000‐odd small businesses employing labour in Australia, a maximum of 295 businesses of all types have been affected by an arbitral case or pending arbitral case. So, by lifting this terrible burden that is currently imposed on small business, a maximum of 300 firms of all sizes around Australia will avoid a day or days in court appearing in an arbitral matter before an industrial commissioner. So it is fair then to draw the following conclusions.

The current act has an absolutely minimal impact on business generally and on small business in particular in this country. The amending bill will have zero impact on small business because so few small businesses have been the subject of a claim for unfair dismissal. The current numbers of applications to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will continue at the same rate or, at best, will decline marginally. There will be limited future impact in the marketplace because the amending bill applies only to future employers and in firms employing fewer than 15 employees. So when this lengthy process, which has evolved over the last 18 months, is presented in the parliament by agreement between some of the parties in this chamber, disallowance motions and Senate inquiries into the current legislation are all about the impact on 300 firms across the entirety of Australia. If that helps small business generally in any way, then I will be amazed.

However, we should not rely purely on what the statistics reveal or on the evidence disclosed by witnesses or the material supplied by the department. Let us turn to the minority report tabled by opposition senators. Let us examine the evidence that goes to the central issue in this debate; that is, the assertion that unfair dismissal laws deter small businesses from taking on new staff.

We know there were some interesting responses to the Australian workplace industrial relations survey of 1995. That survey asked a range of business enterprises, `Why haven't you recruited any employees?' The answer was predictable: 68 per cent of businesses do not need them. For 33 per cent, it was a lack of work, lack of demand for product and a lack of profitability in their own enterprise. Six per cent said that high employment costs were a factor in not hiring labour. But no persons—not one business enterprise which answered that survey—said that unfair dismissal laws were a reason for not employing labour. More importantly, in answer to the specific question, `Why haven't you recruited more employees?' as opposed to, `Why don't you hire any employees?', only six per cent again said high employment costs. None mentioned unfair dismissal laws.

Further surveys tabled before the committee, or provided to the committee in response to questions after the committee concluded its public hearings, gave a similar result. I refer to the May 1997 Yellow Pages small business survey, the August 1997 Yellow Pages small business survey, the Morgan and Banks job index and the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry survey referred to by other senators.

The Yellow Pages small business survey specifically asked small business employers what they believed the barriers were to investment expenditure. The leading responses were: lack of cash flow, 32 per cent; lack of work, 23 per cent; profitability, 19 per cent; the economic climate, 19 per cent; and lack of confidence in the future, four per cent. Clearly, as the report says, all of these re sponses are associated with demand factors operating upon individual firms—that is, insufficient demand for the products that they offer.

The only employment factor mentioned was the general response: cost of employing, three per cent. Even assuming that this response includes alleged disincentives provided by the unfair dismissal laws, this can be only a fraction of the three per cent. We can safely conclude that the survey effectively shows that, as of four months ago—May 1997—small business did not regard the unfair dismissal laws as a barrier to investment or as a disincentive to employment.

Secondly, the survey specifically asked small business people what problems, if any, they were facing at the moment. Not one small business enterprise replied, `Unfair dismissal laws impact on our business, are of concern to our business, prevent us from hiring any labour or additional labour.' Not one respondent advised that survey, which was commissioned by the relevant department, that unfair dismissal laws impacted upon them in any way.

Similarly, the August 1997 small business survey, now only two months old, exposes the reality that small business does not believe that unfair dismissal laws are a disincentive to employment. They were again asked what the barriers were to taking on new employees. Lack of work was the overwhelming response, with 42 per cent. Other factors were: the cost of employing, 18 per cent; superannuation costs, 11 per cent; employment conditions, 11 per cent; economic climate, nine per cent; and lack of cash flow, eight per cent.

The results from the August and the May surveys are the same. Lack of demand factors prevent firms from selling their product in the marketplace to consumers, and that lack of exchange is the reason why they do not hire any or additional labour.

The second specific question asked, unprompted, in the survey was: what should the government be addressing most urgently? What should the government be doing to aid our enterprises to grow and to expand? What did they say? Unfair dismissal laws was the response of just three per cent of small business. Other issues were: tax reform, 10 per cent; unemployment, six per cent; red tape, five per cent; lower taxes and a whole range of other matters. Unfair dismissal laws was at the bottom of the answers and it affected only three per cent.

The Morgan and Banks job index result was similar. In evidence, the department failed to refer to the fact that this survey shows that almost 80 per cent of small businesses were not affected by the unfair dismissal laws in their decisions to hire new staff.

The Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry surveyed firms to determine where businesses ranked unfair dismissal laws. The answer—not surprisingly—was that it rated No. 11 in a field of 58 business issues in terms of their priorities. The other 10 issues were: lack of tax reform, lack of population growth, lack of demand, workers compensation, legislation, federal taxation charges, complexity of regulations, employee oncosts, current state parliamentary systems and government regulation. At No. 11, towards the bottom of the list, was unfair dismissal laws.

The surveys relied upon have generally not supported the government's position in bringing this bill before the Senate. What conclusions can be drawn in summary form from those surveys? That question can only be answered in the context of previous statistical information which showed absolutely no impact on 99.8 per cent of small business.

The conclusions are threefold. Firstly, almost all small business puts a range of other factors—cash flow, profitability, market access, demand factors, unfair competition, red tape—as the principal reasons for declining to hire any or additional labour. Secondly, if prompted—and only if prompted—about six per cent of small business mentioned higher labour costs, which may or may not mean the impact of unfair dismissal laws. Thirdly, it is fair to conclude that the government is not helping small business by attacking a non‐existent problem.

If the problem does not exist, if it does not impact on business generally, if it does not impact upon small business in particular across the breadth of our land, one must ask the question: what is the benefit to be gained to those enterprises when the government puts this bill before the parliament? The answer is simple: no benefit; no help for the future; no assistance in the present; and no change in the business environment in which those firms operate.

Finally, the opposition advances four reasons why it opposes this bill. Firstly, the exemption is unfair to employees. It is inherently unfair to have no right of relief from harsh action by employers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to speak against the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 . There is no good sense to what they have done, apart from the fact that the legislation itself denies people fundamental and basic rights. There are many small businesses which can be rather substantial with 15 employees. . . . even under the old unfair dismissal laws prior to amendment, for every 100 workers dismissed in Australia less than 2 even lodged an unfair dismissal claim.
So where is the problem? It is a problem that has been manufactured. The report goes on to a third conclusion and states:

. . . as a result of the amendments the Government made to the unfair dismissal laws, we can be sure that this figure is now even lower. With a decrease in the number of federal unfair dismissal applications of over 50%, we know that only 1 in 100 dismissals is now challenged by a federal unfair dismissal claim.

So again it just shows that the government have beat this up as much as they can. The authors of the minority report—my colleagues Senator Jacinta Collins and Senator Bishop—then go on to a conclusion which is important. They say:
. . . we can conclude on the basis of these statistics that less than 1 in every 100 involuntary dismissals in small business are now affected by federal unfair dismissal claims.
They also make the comment—it is not highlighted but it really sums it up:
This extraordinary statistic really does lead us to raise the obvious question—where is the overwhelming problem that needs such a drastic solution?
That really is what the government have got to show, and I do not believe they can. Further on at page 22 of the minority report is another interesting conclusion drawn by my colleagues. It says:
. . . on the basis of these statistics we can conclude that in the 9 months since the Government's unfair dismissal laws came into operation:
- 0.005% (or 1 in every 20,000) employing small businesses have been affected by a federal unfair dismissal claim that concluded with an arbitration hearing;
- 0.4% (or 1 in every 250) employing small businesses have even been affected by a federal unfair dismissal claim.

One could hardly say that that is a torrent of unfair claims against small business or something that small business should not be able to cope with, given that we are dealing with the fundamental basic rights of workers to protect themselves against harsh and unconscionable treatment that employers can hand out.

The other thing that I just wanted to look at very briefly is the claim made on page 7 of the majority report—it is the report of the chairman, Senator Ferguson, but it reflects the government's contention. It states:
Employees will continue to have a remedy in relation to unfair dismissal within the Workplace Relations Act 1996 . . . This section—
referring to the current legislation—
removes the employees ability to apply to the Commission on grounds of unfair dismissal.
So the government acknowledges that it does that. Then the report goes on to state:
Legislation is still in place providing the employee with rights in relation to fair employment and if required fair dismissal.
That is a brazen statement which is challenged quite fairly by Senator Bishop and Senator Collins at page 34 of the report. I think that issue is addressed very succinctly by the statement:

We note in passing that the Government has on a number of occasions sought to argue that small business employees will still have a right to relief based on the unlawful termination provisions, especially the prohibition against discrimination. This is true, but those laws do not provide relief where the termination is not discriminatory, but is harsh unjust or unreasonable.

An example of this significant distinction is the following: while the anti-discrimination provisions protect a woman from being dismissed because she is a woman, they do NOT protect a woman from being dismissed because she refused the employer's direction to break the law.

Whilst the government may express some better motive at page 7 of this report, it is quite clear that, for all their words, that does not offer the employee the protection that they now have against harsh, unjust and unconscionable acts on the part of the employer. The whole thrust of what the government is doing will be simply to take away rights of the employee and to make those employees subservient and subjugated to the desire and the wish of the employer. My concern in this is that many of these employees will be women and young people, and they are the people that we should be doing our utmost to protect at the workplace.

In conclusion, the legislation is undoubtedly a sop to the small business community. It does remove a current legal response available to workers. In my view, it strengthens inordinately the power of the employer—not that the employer-employee relationship is ever equal, but this makes the relationship so one-sided that it does not count. The legislation will adversely affect women and young people. I do not believe that this legislation, if passed, will create one job out there in the small business community. It is not a job creation measure. That should be clearly remembered when this bill is being considered. What is at issue here is the dignity of the worker, and the bill should be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Electorate office.

SPEECH.PARA: I always think that small businesses are depressed because they have not got enough work or because they have too much. There never seems to be that happy balance that we all dream about.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's like the rain.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my belief—and I think people in this chamber would endorse it—that small business is also ethical. It goes about its delivery of services and supply of goods in a way that is moral and proper.
The explanatory memorandum published by the government explains the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 and it is important to highlight:

ABS unpublished data for February 1995 indicates that there were 1,921,000 non‐farm private sector wage and salary earners employed by a firm of less than 15 employees (37% of all non‐farm private sector wage and salary earners). BREAK.PARA: The fact that this law does apply to all other employers indicates that it is a law that is fair and reasonable. In other words, the fact that it is proposed that small business be exempt indicates that the law, generally, protecting people's jobs and protecting people from unfair dismissal, is a fair and reasonable proposition. If it were not, this legislation should be aimed at not simply exempting small business from complying with it but exempting all business from complying with it. If it is an unreasonable proposition that there ought to be unfair dismissal laws available to employees, it should be generally taken away.

The proposition is: should there be special exemption for small business? Since the general proposition is that there ought to be laws relating to unfair dismissals for people, businesses and employers generally, that proposition means that the onus is on those proposing to exempt small business to show that small business should be exempt. That has not been made out. I say that because, if it were to be made out, it would have been made out in the second reading speech, which was written to support this proposition, and it does not do that. If I go through the second reading speech, it says:

This bill is intended to ensure that small businesses are exempted from the federal unfair dismissal provisions, in respect of new employees. This exemption is necessary and appropriate, given the special features of small business—and it is necessary, to ensure continuing growth in employment in small business.
