It is not to be retrospective because it would be unfair to make it retrospective; it would disadvantage people who have already been employed. It is an onerous thing to take away a person's ability to bring an action for wrongful dismissal. If that is so, it means that new employees—when I talk about new employees, I mean those people employed from now on—are subject to an onerous law. If it were not onerous, there would be no need to ensure that retrospectivity did not operate. Later on the second reading speech says:
The government has, of course, already made substantial progress in labour market reform, which is and will be of particular benefit to small business.
Again, that is a statement that, as it were, floats in the air and has no argument to back it up. It simply goes on to say:

The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 has changed the federal industrial relations system, and the relationship between federal and state industrial relations systems, providing small business with greater opportunities to develop industrial relations arrangements best suited to their individual circumstances.

Again, that is a statement that is not backed up. Indeed, this idea of an equal bargaining position is a concept that has for long been known to be false. If I can resort to the words of the present Pope in his encyclical centesimus annus letter, he had this to say—and he is talking about Leo the 13th:

The Pope immediately adds another right which the worker has as a person. This is the right to a `just wage', which cannot be left to the `free consent of the parties, so that the employer, having paid what was agreed upon, has done his part and seemingly is not called upon to do anything beyond'.

What is being said there is that the free bargaining position is falsely named because it is not a free bargaining position; it is a position where the balance of power is all a particular way. That is a matter that was commented upon 90 years ago by Mr Justice Higgins of the High Court. On that occasion he was sitting as president of a tribunal which fixed fair wages and conditions. He had this to say when talking about remuneration:

The remuneration could safely have been left to the usual, but unequal, contest, the "higgling of the market" for labour, with the pressure for bread on one side, and the pressure for profits on the other. The standard of "fair and reasonable" must, therefore, be something else; and I cannot think of any other standard appropriate than the normal needs of the average employee, regarded as a human being living in a civilised community.

What is in the interests of the average employee who is regarded as a human being living in a civilised community? Should not a person who is unfairly dismissed have a claim against his or her employer, no matter the size of that employer? If I employed two or three people, can't I be as unjust and as unfair as a corporation that employs a thousand?

TALK.START.PARA: —You'd never do that.

—Senator Calvert, thank you very much; nor would you. But if somebody unlike us with a small labour force did do something along those lines, should not that employee have the same right as any other employee in the community, particularly when, according to the explanatory memorandum to the bill, over 1,900,000 people were employed by small business in February 1995? No doubt that figure has gone up since then.

BREAK.PARA: This is a bill that is misconceived. Small business must be encouraged for all the reasons that I have put forward. But where is the evidence—and Senator Bishop, Senator Jacinta Collins, Senator Hogg and Senator Mackay have already gone into this—that supports the proposition that the exclusion of small business from the law that generally applies to others will give small business the fillip that is needed? The people running small business need to be able to let their initiative, their imagination and their ability to judge the market have full flow. They need to have the ability to meet the many costs that impinge upon them. They also need to have the ability to meet the various regulations that are imposed upon them. They need to be given the ability to sell quality products or deliver services in the best of ways to the community. That is the sort of thing that should be encouraged and should be looked at rather than saying, `Look, the solution to all the difficulties that small business has is an ability to hire and fire at will.'

I know, and this is the interesting thing, that a lot of other regulations and laws under the Workplace Relations Act will apply to small business. People have made the distinction that they are subject to the Workplace Agreements Act. All those provisions apply except, if this legislation is passed, the unfair dismissal provisions. It seems extraordinary that so much faith can be put on a proposition for which there is very little evidence. I will read the minister's second reading speech again, In support of the proposition that I have just put, the minister's second reading speech says:

The exemption is from the federal unfair dismissal provisions only. Employees will still be protected by the Workplace Relations Act. Section 170CK protects employees against dismissal because of any discriminatory reason.

Then it goes on. It is not that this legislation, as I have said, exempts small business from most of the provisions of the Workplace Relations Act, but this, as it were, is a sop thrown to small business by the government as a focus for what is seen as their discontent. The passage of this act will not make small business successful. This second reading speech does not pretend to give any justification for what is intended. I read again from it:

And Madam President, this is the crucial point—this exemption is not just about removing a burden from small business, it is about the positive employment benefits of the expanded job opportunities that will surely result from the removal of that burden.

There is no argument put. There are no figures quoted. There is no proposition from some learned professor put into this second reading speech. There is just the bald statement that is left to hang out as a justification for a very dramatic move—and this is a dramatic move—to remove this very crucial right of people who work for employers who employ 15 or fewer employees.

Small business must be encouraged. People who run small business have all sorts of pressures on them. But the proposition in this legislation that seeks to take away rights from certain employees—rights that all other employees have—is not the way forward. If this legislation is passed this parliament will not be facing up to the real issues that confront small business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —In opposing the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill , I want to congratulate Senator Cooney on his contribution which, as always, was analytical, learned and very useful to the debate. He put a number of the arguments very succinctly, as have all of my colleagues. I think the absence of serious debate from the other side does not on this occasion reflect any pressure on the government to finish the legislative program but rather the government's lack of arguments in debating this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This is clearly not a bill which they are able to support with any intellectual argument. It is very much about politics rather than industrial relations or making good law. I will come to that issue a little later.

I want to start my contribution in this debate by declaring for those who like to make a big issue about this that I am a former union official and I have had some practical experience in unfair dismissal cases. While some people like to argue that that disqualifies you from such debates, I actually think it gives you some relevantexperience. I have had the experience of conducting unfair dismissal cases mainly in the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission but once or twice in the federal commission. It is very useful experience to bring to this debate. I must say that I won some and I lost some, but, hopefully, I learnt from that experience what law should be applied in such cases.

The other thing I bring to this debate is some experience in managing small offices—not a traditional small business. I, like Senator Cooney, have a great deal of sympathy for small business people who are struggling to hold their operations together and are confronted with employment issues, taxation issues and business confidence issues on a daily basis. It is a very difficult job and there are complex and difficult issues that confront them in the employment area. I am not at all unsympathetic to that issue.

Both as secretary of a union which employed three or four staff and as secretary of the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party, which was a smaller small business when I finished than when I started as I had the responsibility for downsizing that organisation, I did learn something about the difficulties of running a small business. It was well after the heyday, Senator Alston, when money was aplenty in that organisation.

I do have some appreciation of the difficulties in managing the aspirations of staff, meeting the financial constraints of the organisation and trying to make sure that fairness is applied to employees in those situations. The reason I enter this debate is not so much because of my experience, because I think my colleagues, particularly those on the committee and Senator Mackay and Senator Cooney, have really taken us through what is a compelling case against the bill, but rather because I am outraged at the underlying principle at the heart of this bill.

We are being asked as a parliament not to offer protection to those employees who have been unfairly dismissed by an employer in a harsh, unjust or unreasonable way if they happen to be working for an employer who employs less than 15 people. We are being asked to put aside the principle we recently endorsed and that this parliament has endorsed throughout its history of providing protection to employees in such circumstances.

On this occasion we are being asked to put aside the principle of providing protection for those who have been treated harshly, unjustly or unreasonably because they are employed by an employer who employs less than 15 people. That is the core principle at the heart of this bill. The government wants to make the case that, because an employer employs less than 15 people, the principle that we have accepted on the government's initiative as being a fair rule to apply to unfair dismissal in this country should be now set aside.

In all of my experience, I have never come across the question of the number of employees who are employed by an employer being a central issue in an unfair dismissal case. I was involved in a whole range of different unfair dismissal cases, from nurses who were dismissed from hospitals to bar workers who were dismissed from small clubs and hotels. Never once when arguing the merits of the case or the principles involved did the issue of the number of other employees employed by the employer seem to be at the heart of the dispute. I do not remember it ever being raised by an employer as a justification of their position, as a defence for dismissing someone. We generally worked on the basis that, if you went to the Industrial Relations Commission, you had to come in with clean hands and we sought industrial fairness. In most cases that was meted out, even though on occasions I was on the wrong side of the argument.

We have been asked, in this parliament, to endorse discrimination against people on the basis of the number of fellow employees employed by their employer. It is a ludicrous proposition to put. It is straight discrimination against those persons who happen to work for an employer who employs less than 15 people. The principle that the government wishes to apply to unfair dismissal will not apply to an employment context where there are 16 people employed. It will not apply where there are 30 people. It will not apply where there are 100 people. It will apply where there are less than 15 people. There is no rationale, no justification, no argument advanced for this proposition that holds any water.

It is worse than that. It is a principle the government says should not apply to existing employees. It will only apply to future employees. We will have a situation where two workers might be dismissed for the same offence, say, some activity on the job which the employer finds unreasonable. If you are employed before this act comes into operation you would have the right to pursue an unfair dismissal case. You could take your case to the Industrial Relations Commission. You could have it argued on its merits and if the employer had been harsh, unjust or unreasonable you could get your job back. If you were employed the day after this bill, if carried, was enacted—tough luck.

Different rules apply purely because of the date on which you were employed. There could be two employees sacked for the same offence and one would have the right to recourse and one would not. What is the principle in this? What on earth drives this sort of arrangement? There is no principle. There is no rationale. It is another case of discrimination.

Equally, there could be two employees sacked from the same industry at around the same time for the same offence. One would have a right to challenge unfair dismissal if they were working for an employer with more than 15 employees; the other one, who could be working next door in a similar factory, shop, solicitor's office or whatever the busi ness enterprise, would not have a right to challenge unfair dismissal if they were working for an employer with less than 15 employees. They could be sacked for exactly the same offence, but the determining factor for whether they could go to the Industrial Relations Commission and seek justice and a fair hearing is the number of fellow employees employed in the enterprise.

This is absolutely ridiculous. There is no justice, no fairness, in that proposition. As I say, you are discriminating against different classes of employees for no particular reason. There is no defence for this. The government has not been prepared to try to argue the merits of those sorts of propositions. It has not been prepared to try to defend that sort of discrimination because there is no defence.

What makes this even more ridiculous is that the government is seeking to amend its own legislation, the Workplace Relations Act, for which it only recently gained support in the Senate, might I say despite the opposition of opposition senators. It was heralded as a triumph for the coalition government—a new age of industrial relations. But, almost immediately following its passage, the government is seeking to amend it. Again, there is no rationale for that.

I remember the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) beaming, holding hands and cavorting with my new party colleague Senator Kernot, celebrating this new legislation and how it represented a fair and just solution. But now it is apparently not good enough. There must be some reason for this change. It seems to me the onus is on the government to prove why we must amend the act that they triumphantly got through this parliament only recently. They must prove the case. They must establish the need, the rationale, and set out the principles that they think should apply. They have not done that. They cannot do that. There is no acceptable rationale, there is no principle at the basis of this, and there is no demonstrated need.

My colleagues have already outlined the experience of business. They have put paid to the assertions that somehow this change is required by small business. This is a non sense. This is about politics, but I will come back to that in a second. I think it is really incumbent upon the government to prove their case as to why they want to amend their legislation, which they said was going to transform industrial relations in this country, so soon after its passage. In my view the parliament should reject the bill because the government has not made out a case for that change to happen. There is no rationale and there is no principle underlying this legislation.

I do want to make one point which I think is important. The government claims that this bill is necessary to improve employment prospects for people in small business and that the furore regarding the previous Labor government's unfair dismissal laws has left an environment in which small business is unwilling to employ people because of the fear of possible unfair dismissal cases that may be taken against them. I think the government has failed to prove its case in that regard.

But an important element of this debate is that we had new industrial relations legislation put through by the coalition government which radically altered those unfair dismissal laws to make them far less onerous on small business. I do not want to argue the toss about the so-called Brereton laws, but the point is that those laws have gone. The government has had its way in terms of unfair dismissal and we are now operating under their new laws. So there is no impediment in that regard to small business.

The key argument, it seems to me, is the issue of job security. All the surveys, all the data put out by business and all the public opinion surveys illustrate the greatest problem facing the economy at the moment. It is not inflation, it is not interest rates; it is the issue of job security and resultant lack of confidence. Lack of confidence is stopping growth in the Australian economy. Retail spending is not growing as well as would be expected given the economic conditions. People are not prepared to spend money.

The reason—widely understood, I think, in the Australian community—is the concern about job security. People are concerned about their jobs, concerned about their potential to hold their jobs or to find new jobs, and they are therefore reluctant to spend—reluctant to invest in homes, new cars and other retail purchases. What is the government going to do? The government is going to introduce a law that says, `If you work for an employer who has less than 15 employees you can be sacked tomorrow and it does not matter. You have no come back. You cannot go to the industrial umpire and argue your case. Even if it is harsh, unjust and unreasonable, you are out the door—stiff bickies, you're gone.' This is the government's initiative that they have introduced into the equation that I described about job insecurity in Australia.

If anything, this bill will prevent the creation of employment in this community because it will do nothing to encourage those in jobs to spend. Insecurity and the unwillingness of people to expend money is holding back the economy. If people spent more, more jobs would be created as the economy and activity grew.

This bill will do the exact opposite of what is claimed by the government. It will breed further job insecurity. People will not be willing to take on new jobs with small employers. They will be concerned about their prospects with small employers because they will have read the press that basically says, `If you work for an employer with 15 or less people you don't have any right to seek protection against unfair dismissal.' That will feed into the already existing job insecurity scenario that is so prevalent in Australia today.

I reject the claims that this bill will assist employment growth. In fact I assert that, if this bill is passed, it will lead to greater job insecurity, work against growth in the economy and therefore prevent the creation of the jobs needed to solve what is a growing unemployment problem.

I want to put one final argument. If people are listening to this debate they will be wondering: what is this all about? There is no principle involved. We have demonstrated that there is no demand from industry. The practical effect of this is relatively small in terms of the treatment of unfair dismissal cases in the Industrial Relations Commission. Why would the government be doing this? Quite frankly, at first I was a bit perplexed but the only answer I can come to is that the government is seriously looking for a double dissolution trigger.

If you look at the history of this dispute, you will see that the government started off, passing its Workplace Relations Act. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) then announced in March this year that we would have new regulations which went to exclude employees from the protection of federal unfair dismissal laws who work for a small business with no more than 15 employees who had less than a year's continuous service. He said we were going to have a regulation that had those two aspects to it. Those regulations were disallowed by the Senate, as senators would be aware. In mid-July this year, the Prime Minister said he would be prepared to seek a double dissolution if the Senate failed to pass this bill which he introduced following the disallowance of those regulations.

But this bill goes further than those regulations proposed. The only criterion now included in terms of the exclusion from protection from unfair dismissal is this sole question of the 15 employees or less. The reference to their first year's continuous service went out the door. What we have seen is an upping of the ante. I think Mr Reith was asked by the Prime Minister to provide a double dissolution trigger so that the government could leave its options open in terms of a double dissolution election next year.

I am not one of those senators—and there are some in this place—who concentrates on these things and who speculates about when double dissolutions are going to be held and when there is going to be an election. I usually try to avoid that debate because I find it is a very circular argument. But I think it is the case that, on this occasion, Mr Reith, as Leader of the House, was asked to find a trigger. I think he thought, `If you want a job done, do it yourself. I'll make sure it's in my area. I'll go out and deliver for the government in terms of the trigger.'

BREAK.PARA: What we have seen is that the government progressively toughened their stance in terms of their proposals for unfair dismissal for small business. Some very important issues are canvassed in the annual report of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. These issues involve some of the changes that are occurring in Australia's food standards. For instance, the section on page 15 of the annual report deals with the World Trade Organisation. It says that the authority fulfils Australia's obligations to the WTO in relation to food standards by taking into account the requirements of the Codex Alimentarius when assessing proposed changes to the Australian food standards code.

That is not necessarily a good thing. It means the lowest common denominator. It means that, if we want to have a higher standard than the Codex Alimentarius, we have to justify it. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to discuss the issue of Medicare office closures and the impact this is having on local communities. Of particular concern to me is the closure of the East Victoria Park Medicare office in Western Australia within the federal division of Swan. It is important to note that this closure in East Victoria park is like so many others that are going on around the nation. Of equal concern is that these closures do not stand alone. They are apparently part of a broad health policy that has seen a fundamental re-evaluation of the priorities of health care.

SPEECH.PARA: Predominantly, this re-evaluation has seen a shift from health care provided on the basis of need to health care provided on the basis of those who can afford it. Some of those broad based health policies that are in tune with this government's approach are cuts to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, cuts to the dental care scheme, cuts to the funding of public hospitals and failure of the government to adequately compensate doctors through Medicare, thus shifting future cost burdens to the community.

Now the government has decided to reduce the accessibility of the major Australian health‐care provider, Medicare. This decision is made against a background of community support for Medicare and a belief in the provision of services by Medicare offices. This has been validated by consistently high client satisfaction reports from around the nation.

The government has underestimated the role that Medicare offices play in local communities and has added to the perception in the community that the government seeks to implement policy that disadvantages those most in need. The Medicare office in East Victoria Park is a classic case in point. This office is situated in an area of metropolitan Western Australia that is seeing an increase in the density of its dwellings.

Importantly, much of this population density is the result of young families moving into the region and elderly people moving into smaller accommodation units within the area. These two groups in particular rely heavily on the Medicare office in East Victoria Park and benefit from its close regional proximity. The importance of this Medicare office is highlighted by the fact that it deals with approximately 40,000 claims per year.

BREAK.PARA: Much of the government's—and the local federal member's—argument in regard to closure of the Medicare office is based on the fact that there are three other such offices within 15 kilometres of East Victoria Park. The government argues that the clients of the East Victoria Park office have other offices within a close proximity. Of course, these other offices deal with a large number of claims per year already.

I believe the government has missed the point. The fact that there are other offices within a relatively close distance but that the East Victoria Park office processes 163 claims per day highlights the important role it plays in the local community and the reliance of families living in the area on local infrastructure. For many, use of another office would drag people out of the local region and congest already busy offices in other areas. For those young families without access to a vehicle during working hours, travelling into the CBD to lodge a Medicare claim is extremely inconvenient. For elderly people, public transport into the CBD or large shopping areas can be a trying experience.

The government's response to this argument is that Medicare clients can mail in their Medicare claims and have reimbursement processed through an automatic deposit into a bank account. However, this process ensures that those sections of the community with low cash reserves are without cash for a number of days and an expense is incurred through postage and bank debit fees by way of automatic bank deposit.

For example, a family with three children who all catch the flu in the one week could be faced with bills of around $90 in GP fees alone and on top of this is the added cost of medication. A process through which claims are mailed into the CBD and then processed would ensure that families could be without a significant amount of their weekly income for a number of days. For most families, $90 in one week is, of course, a considerable amount of money.

For elderly Australians who may visit a doctor once a fortnight, the cost of mailing Medicare claims forms would be an overall increase in health‐care costs to that patient. For pensioners in today's economic climate, this is another intrusion on their lives.

This issue goes to the heart of a number of matters. Firstly, members of the community have had another service taken away from their local community. The rationale behind local offices is that they are placed in the area to serve the public. They provide an opportunity to discuss problems, are a contact point, and are invaluable to those in need. For those with an affluent lifestyle or self‐transport, this may not be an imperative; for some it is. Young families and those who really need care and support run the risk of being marginalised. It is not enough to see that their local branches are all being centralised, or that banks are closing offices and installing electronic devices to dispense cash; they have to tolerate another erosion in the service level to their local community.

This is a community that has suffered much in the last year. Demand for local business has been down, with many closures and falling employment. Now this will be compounded by the withdrawal of one more important government or semi-government service. It seems logical to me that a public service that brings 40,000 people a year into the local area would produce some run‐off for affected local business. This is a point that has been entirely overlooked by the local member.

Thirdly, many of our local communities are fragile entities. They depend partly on business and partly on government for survival. When either of these elements is missing, they are subject to damage. When government makes the decision to remove services, the price is sometimes not always evident by simply an accounting bottom line. The cost is hidden; it is the deterioration of the local community. When this Medicare office closes, the department next door is rationalised. There is precious little for the local small businesses.

Fourthly, what of the staff and families that are currently employed in these offices? They have been forced to transfer to other locations, many having served the pre-existing locality for many years.

Another vexing point is the government's decisions to close these offices at this point in time. The Health Insurance Commission claims that, within the next 12 months, electronic lodgments will be available for Medicare within the office of the local GP. If this is the case, why does the government seek to place a financial burden and cost on the local community of East Victoria Park at this time? If the government were concerned with the interests of the local community, they would have closed the Medicare office at a time concurrent with the introduction of electronic lodgment in the GP's office.

Finally, I will comment about the impact of Medicare office closure in other states around the country. In a review conducted by AGB McNair, a number of problems were identified. The lack of personal contact in claim processing meant that the process of correction was a costly and time consuming delay. The review identified that more than 33 per cent of claims lodged were incorrect or required more information. Had these claims been lodged in person at the local office, problems could have been rectified on the spot. Instead, it took a number of days for problems to be dealt with, and added to an already considerable delay in cost reimbursement for patients. In addition to this, a whole range of other problems were identified in the new process. Unfortunately, I do not have time to deal with them tonight.

It is evident that the Medicare office closure in East Victoria Park is part of a broad government policy to cut back health care services. The government has illustrated its first priority to be immediate financial savings as opposed to public service that contributes to the local community in a number of ways.

It is an issue at the core of community concerns regarding this government and their commitment to service, and it highlights yet again the failure of this government to understand the importance of universal health care and accessibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about my experiences as part of our current inquiry into the status of teachers and, in particular, to talk about the day of the hearing on Wednesday last week, which was held in Maningrida and Djamada, two communities at the northern extremes of the Northern Territory. Because the hearings were not recorded on Hansard , I want to place those experiences on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: The day was very memorable for a number of reasons, but primarily for the insights it provided into remote Aboriginal schooling in the territory. This was my first experience in an isolated Aboriginal community, and it was indeed an enlightening one.

I was unaware—like most Australians, I suspect—that although Aboriginal people, particularly in remote parts of Australia, still speak in their indigenous tongue, many Aboriginal people speak two, three and sometimes many more languages. But many speak little English and, for them, the need to do so has little relevance.

The Northern Territory has worked very hard to train Aboriginal teachers through its Batchelor College, and it is educating Aboriginal teachers within their own communities as well. At Maningrida the school is trilingual, and there are two main indigenous languages used in its primary level classrooms. But, in that region, Aboriginal people sometimes live a nomadic lifestyle, and hunting and fishing are often a way of life for them.

Because white culture's schooling is just one aspect of their lives, the indigenous community does not always see the relevance of education, particularly in English. For the first time in my life, I was acutely aware of the way in which we are still imposing a very foreign culture on these people. We expect them to value school and learning, and to receive that learning from people whose culture is so very different from their own.

For some families it is even culturally inappropriate for children to have more knowledge than their parents. There are cultural differences in the status that we accord teachers and those of the traditional Aboriginal communities, and there are enormous complexities associated with those relationships.

BREAK.PARA: We appoint times for schooling, which makes absolutely no sense to many Aboriginal people or even, I might say, to the white teachers who teach there—especially in the hot season. When temperatures are close to 40 degrees in the mid-afternoon, it is impossible for either the teachers or the students to concentrate.

We heard up there that attendance in school is spasmodic and depends on other cultural events, such as the needs of the families, primarily for food collection, and for ceremonial occasions which are numerous and very rarely predictable.

We heard too that the Northern Territory government staffed schools like Maningrida on an average attendance. This means that, early in the school term or when the weather is not too hot, there may be a maximum attendance, and classes which are designed for 30 or so students may swell to 50 or 60. Eventually, those students who do not fit in, are less enthusiastic or do not get the attention of the teacher, drift away. It is not infrequent for a teacher to face a class of different children altogether from one day to the next. A large majority of Aboriginal children have hearing problems associated with infections and the services—or rather lack of them—in the area. The obstacles to teaching and to learning are enormous.

In the wet season, many communities and families are cut off, and this is yet another reason why children do not attend school. I was told that the difference between Aboriginal languages and English is enormous. They are so different that very few white teachers—or balanda, as they are called—or even those who have lived in the area for some time, learn an Aboriginal language. The reason for this is, as I understand it, the very great difference in the structures of those languages and English. That was a lesson for me in how difficult it is for Aboriginal people too whose first language is not English to learn to communicate in English—and not just to communicate in English but to learn in English.

One of the points that I wanted to make most strongly today was that we need to realise that Aboriginal children do not have English as a second language status in terms of the additional support that many immigrant children have, for instance. This, in itself, it seems to me, is a denial of the fact, which became so obvious to us in the Northern Territory, that learning English and learning in English is a very difficult task for so many of these children.

In persuading children that they should come to school, it is also very difficult to put the argument that children need education to improve their career prospects. By and large, the only opportunity for children to get jobs in communities as remote as these is by moving away, and to do so is not always culturally or socially appropriate. Here in Canberra we rely upon statistics on attendance in schools and retention rates to measure achievement in education, and I myself have drawn attention to the very low levels of both achievement and retention in the Northern Territory.

The committee went from Darwin, where it had a day's hearing, to Maningrida and then on by single engine aircraft to Djamada, which is a very small outpost community of about 12 or so houses. After we arrived at the airstrip, we picked our way across a rubbish strewn area between the houses, many of which were uninhabited, to a women's shelter. This was an open structure which did at least provide us with shade and a semblance of a cool breeze. We sat on the floor in this shelter with visiting balanda teachers and local Aboriginal teachers and we discussed the issues for teachers in this very hot, dry and, to our urban eyes, I would have to say, inhospitable environment.

The visiting teachers who come to Djamada for usually three days a month have to bring along a tent because there is no other accommodation in this area. There is a tank of bore water but very few other services. I left there thinking that it was quite remarkable, really, that education of the balanda variety takes place at all.

For me, this experience was a great education and a reminder of the enormous value that our committee system brings to the Senate—one which takes us out to speak very directly with people so, no matter how remote they are from Canberra, they are actually able to speak directly with the decision makers. I was also reminded of how often the decisions that we make in this place affect people in the way that they do, regardless of the distance they might be away from this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening, I rise to recount an experience I had Saturday week ago on 11 October when I met with some of the councillors and the CEO from the Roma Council to the west of Brisbane. I draw this to the attention of the Senate this evening because I thought they said some very pertinent things about the frustration that is felt by regional centres in the bush.

SPEECH.PARA: Their first concern, their major concern, was the fact that people are moving away for two reasons—that is, to study and to seek work. But, of course, their prime concern in that was the fact that these people never return. The reason for that is there are no employment opportunities to be found in the community. In talking with the CEO and the councillors from the Roma Council, I found that I felt a sense of frustration on their part. I think they felt that the government, whether it be state or federal, does not have the answer to the biggest problem facing their community.

Whilst they were able to tell me that tourism had assisted to some extent in stabilising some employment in the area, it was not going to be a major contributor to employment growth in the area. So, whilst there was some good coming out of tourism, tourism would never provide the answers to the employment needs of Roma and its surrounding districts.

They said that there was a dilemma in the rural and regional areas of Australia in providing real jobs for people, and they complained to me that there was no strategy in place to help regional centres either survive or grow. I would imagine that, if one took the opportunity to move throughout Queensland and, albeit, other regional areas throughout Australia, one would find a similar concern being raised. They did raise with me, though, the fact that there were key regional centres in Queensland around which governments could plan growth, if governments had the mind to do so.

They raised an interesting issue: that all local governments in Queensland apparently have to produce a five‐and 10‐year plan. But they said no such plan was forced upon the likes of the federal government. They thought that this, in part, led to some of the difficulties that confronted them. Whilst they had a plan, neither the state government nor the federal government necessarily had a plan to address the issues and the solutions that they perceived.

They believe that a reasonable strategic plan may well ameliorate the difficulties currently being faced in the bush. In their plans they have had to address issues like population, infrastructure needs and developments, which will create employment within their regions. However, they say that no such demand, of course, has been placed on either the state or federal governments. Whilst there is much rhetoric out there, they say there is no real commitment to assist major regional hubs such as Roma. They say that there needs to be a plan.

They went on to give a very interesting example of how planning—or no planning—fails them. They gave me an example of a problem that they were having with the state government in Queensland and the bureaucrats. They were most anxious to be competitive in a bid to secure a gaol in their region. They estimate that the gaol would create some 285 jobs. They concede that about 120 of those jobs would be imported from outside, by specialists needed to run and operate the gaol, but there would be at least another 165 local jobs created. It would also put money into the community to generate other jobs, so they saw a flow‐on effect there.

However, they ran into two obstacles. The two obstacles were: firstly, bureaucrats; and, secondly, the state government, because both ignored any sites west of the Great Dividing Range. I fear that this is part of the problem that we have in our nation. We forget that substantial numbers of people do live west of the Great Dividing Range and do want government support and government initiatives to help them keep their communities alive and thriving. Of course, they were fairly dogged in their approach to this issue. Whilst they had been excluded in the first instance, they ended up convincing the bureaucrats, and to some extent I believe the state government, to at least consider that that the region should be eligible to compete for the siting of a gaol.

They showed resolve and one must admire their resolve in sticking to their guns. If only the Queensland government could have the faith in these places inasmuch as they have the faith in themselves. I think that is an important thing; these rural communities do have faith in themselves and do believe in themselves, but they are looking for real government support, whether it be at the state government level or at the federal government level. Roma is far from finished as a viable and vibrant competitor with other sites throughout south‐east Queensland for this goal.

The second thing that the councillors drew to my attention was the fact that they have being trying to establish a fertiliser plant in Roma. That does not sound overly exciting but they point out that given their location, a fertiliser plant makes great sense. The unfortunate story about the fertiliser plant is that its establishment has been launched on at least three or four occasions and on each occasion it has failed for a number of reasons. Of course, this time looks like being the most positive opportunity for this project to get off the ground.

They have natural gas flowing past the front door, so to speak, and they have ample supplies of water to support the manufacture of urea in the area. However, they need venture capital. Whilst they have a long way to go, they have hope. I believe the federal government should be intervening in these areas to support councils, such as the Roma council, which do have faith, hope and a vision. Whilst they have a forward looking approach to life, they rely on government to step in and to assist them. One would hope that the federal government will take initiatives to help places such as Roma and com munities that are fighting for their survival. One would hope that those who reside west of the divide are not deserted, as they seem to have been by this government. One would hope that governments, both state and federal, which have the opportunity to create a climate and an environment to give more major regional centres the boost that they need, will do so.

What they really need are jobs—real, lasting jobs—and, of course, they want government intervention to assist them in achieving that. I think that was the real story that came out of my visit to Roma and I think it is worthwhile putting on the Hansard record this evening. I believe that the federal government should act now to show it cares about rural Australia, to show that it is desirous of helping those people who have a vision for the future—a vision which will maintain a vibrant and viable rural and regional Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Instruments on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to Australia's treaty obligations relating to indigenous people:
(1) What is the full list of treaties and other international instruments signed by Australia that relate to indigenous people.
(2) What legislation has the Commonwealth implemented to enact treaty obligations relating to indigenous people.
(3) What treaty obligations relating to indigenous people remain unimplemented through legislation.

(4) Which treaties relating to indigenous people, if any, has Australia not yet joined as a signatory, distinguishing between those : (a) in which negotiations are still underway; and (b) in which Australia holds a contrary view to their intention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are a number of key treaties which act to protect the rights of all Australians, including indigenous peoples. These are:
‐ the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination, ratified by Australia in 1975;
‐ the Convention on the Rights of the Child, ratified by Australia in 1990;
‐ the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, ratified by Australia in 1980;
‐ the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, ratified by Australia in 1975; and
‐ the International Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women, ratified by Australia in 1983.

In addition, Australia has ratified International Labor Organisation (ILO) Convention 86, Concerning the Maximum Length of Contracts of Employment with Indigenous Workers (ratified by Austral ia in 1973) and is considering its position with respect to ILO Convention 169, the Convention Concerning Indigenous and Tribal Peoples in Indigenous Countries, both of which specifically address the rights of indigenous peoples.
A listing of treaties to which Australia is a party is available at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's Internet site , which can be found at http://www.austlii.edu.au/dfat/ .
(2) Key legislation which implements treaty obligations and which is relevant to indigenous peoples includes:
‐ the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989;
‐ the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984;
‐ the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976;
‐ the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991;
‐ the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986;
‐ the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Act 1995;
‐ the Native Title Act 1993;
‐ the Racial Discrimination Act 1975; and
‐ the Racial Hatred Act 1995.
(3) It is Australian practice not to ratify or accept treaty obligations until domestic law and practice complies with the provisions of the treaty under consideration.
4(a)—(b) Treaties relating specifically to indigenous peoples which are under consideration by Australia have been referred to in the answer to Question one.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Surveillance Guidelines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 August 1997 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can a copy be provided of the draft or completed tender documents for the contract involving the hire of private investigators by the department to conduct surveillance of welfare recipients in a pilot project due to begin in September 1997.

(2) Can a copy be provided of any guidelines that will be attached to these documents, that will set out the behaviour and responsibilities of any private investigators hired, what established guidelines and regulations they are governed by and to whom they are accountable.
(3) What changes were made to the draft guidelines after officers of the department discussed them with officers employed to assist the Privacy Commissioner.
(4) (a) What types of benefit recipients will the pilot project be targeting; and (b) what geographical or socio‐economic areas will be targeted.
(5) To which organisations or companies has the department released the selective tender.
(6) Will the Minister supply the name of the company to whom the tender has been let.
(7) Will the Minister supply the dates of the pilot project and the details of the pilot that have been supplied to the successful tenderer.

(8) Will the Minister supply copies of any guidelines or protocols that will be, or are being, supplied to officers of the department who will oversee these pilots and who will be responsible for deciding which clients are targeted during the pilot.
(9) Will any cases that would have been referred to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) now be dealt with by the department using private investigators.
(10) If the AFP undertake investigations of some cases, what is the difference between a case dealt with by the department and one referred to the AFP.
(11) If a case is referred to the AFP, must the AFP undertake an investigation of that case; if not, what does the department do.
(12) Has the AFP provided any guidance to the department about the types of cases it will investigate; if so, what guidance.

(13) (a) What elements of a contract used to engage a private investigator will be commercial‐in‐confidence; (b) will these elements be the same in every agreement; and (c) why are these elements commercial‐in‐confidence.
(14) Why is the department using private detectives rather than the AFP to investigate cases of alleged social security fraud.

(15) Will private investigators be bound by the same regulations as the AFP when they are carrying out their work for the department; if not, which regulations will not bind them that would bind a policeman.

(16) If a private investigator carrying out his or her tasks for the department is subject to a complaint from a person being investigated : (a) how will that be dealt with; and (b) will the outcome of the complaint be enforceable.
(17) Will private investigators be doing any tasks that would normally be undertaken by the police.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows :

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A copy of the tender documents have been made available to you.
(2) Draft `Guidelines for Surveillance Activity' produced by Centrelink for the purpose of this pilot are also contained in the tender documentation provided to you.

(3) A number of changes were made to the draft guidelines as a result of comments by staff from the Privacy Commissioner's Office. The majority of these changes related to the evaluation of the pilot in regard to costs and benefits and ensuring that key privacy standards are included in the contract, not just in the guidelines.

(4) (a) The pilot will assist in investigations of Newstart and Disability Support Pension customers, focussing in particular on allegations of undisclosed income from employment and disability support pensioners who may have significantly misrepresented the degree to which they are incapacitated.
(4) (b) It is proposed to conduct the pilot over a three month period in the Sydney metropolitan and Gold Coast/South Brisbane geographical areas.
(5) A list of the organisations or companies who received the selective tender will be made available to your office.

(6) A decision on the successful tenderers is yet to be made. It is proposed to contract two or three firms in each location for the purpose of the pilot. Once contracts have been signed, the name of the contractors, a broad description of the work to be provided and an estimated cost will be matters of public record and announced in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

(7) It is proposed the pilot be for a duration of three months and will commence upon completion of contract negotiation. Details concerning the pilot, along with guidelines contracted firms are expected to follow, are included in the draft `Guidelines for Surveillance Activity' produced by Centrelink for the purpose of this pilot. A copy of these guidelines has been provided to you.
(8) Guidelines for Centrelink staff overseeing this pilot are currently in draft form. Once they have been finalised a copy will be provided to your office.

(9) Cases currently referred to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) will continue to be referred to that organisation in line with `Guidelines for Referral and Acceptance of Social Security Matters for Investigation by the Australian Federal Police' which have been in place since November 1995. These Guidelines were developed by the Department of Social Security and the AFP and reflect the policy directions contained in the Fraud Control Policy of the Commonwealth. I can arrange for a copy of the Guidelines to be provided to your Office. Cases provided to private investigators will be those which would not generally have been referred to the AFP and are cases where normal investigation methods have not produced conclusive outcomes.
(10) Under the above Guidelines cases which are mandatory for AFP referral are :
. identity related fraud;
. apprehension of violence against a Centrelink officer;
. bribery and corruption (including attempted) of a Centrelink officer;
. the alleged fraud appears to be part of a larger scale criminal activity;
. politically sensitive; and
. where there is an indication of related offences against other government agencies.

As explained in 4(a) above, cases referred to the successful tenderers will be those which contain allegations of undisclosed income from employment and cases involving disability support pensioners who may have significantly misrepresented the degree to which they are incapacitated. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resources Economics (ABARE) conducting a survey of sawmills in Western Australia.
(2) Is the survey being conducted in co-operation with the Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia (FIFWA); if so, why is ABARE conducting the survey in co-operation with FIFWA.

(3) Given that FIFWA overwhelmingly represents the perceived interests of the native forest sector of the Western Australia timber industry, is FIFWA an appropriate organisation for ABARE to work with to produce an unbiased report.
(4) Who designed the survey that is being conducted in Western Australia.
(5) Who was consulted about the design of the survey.

(6) (a) Will the survey examine just sawmilling, or will it also examine wood processing, for example, particle board, veneer, furniture, et cetera; and (b) if both, what categories of wood processing will be investigated.
(7) Will the survey investigate the current situation and future potential of mills (and processing plants) that do not rely on native forest logs, including pine and bluegum mills (and plants).
(8) Will the survey investigate the opportunities for those mills (and plants) that are currently based on native forest logs to change their operations to instead use non-native forest logs.
(9) Will the survey document the number of sawmills based on native forest logs that have been closed in the past 20 years, and the number of workers laid off as a result.

(10) Will the survey produce a reliable set of data in relation to the actual current number of employees in the: (a) native forest sawmill industry; (b) plantation-based sawmill industry: (c) native forest wood processing industry; (d) plantation wood processing industry; if so, will that data be published.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) ABARE did seek the cooperation of the Forest Industries Federation of Western Australia (FIFWA) in order to encourage a high level of participation of mill owners and companies in the survey.
(3) FIFWA is not engaged in the collection or the analysis of the data gathered in the survey.
(4) ABARE designed the survey.

(5) ABARE consulted with the Western Australian Departments of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) and Resource Development, FIFWA, the Guild of Furniture Manufacturers and Bunnings Forest Products.

(6) All sawmillers/companies currently with licenses to purchase logs, both hardwood and softwood, from CALM were included in the sawmill sample. This includes companies currently involved i n particle board, MDF and veneer production. Companies which buy sawn timber for manufacturing processes, such as for furniture production, have not been included in the sawmill survey.

(7) No, a separate economic analysis will examine value adding opportunities for the Western Australian log and timber based industries over the life of the Western Australian Regional Forestry Agreement, taking into account potential log availabilities from both native forests and plantations.
(8) No, such issues will be addressed in a separate analysis of the value adding opportunities.
(9) No, only existing sawmills are participating in the survey.

(10) Details of current sawmill and processing employment, as outlined for part 6 of this question, will be provided to the Regional Forest Agreement assessment process for Western Australia. Information by sawmill category will not be published where the publication of such data breaches data confidentiality provisions by allowing individual sawmills or companies to be identified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the interconnection of Queensland to the national electricity grid (the corridor of which will run through some southern parts of Queensland):
(1) Is any Federal funding being provided to this project; if so: (a) how much; and (b) in what form, that is, can details be provided of that funding.
(2) Was any environmental impact assessment undertaken for this project.
(3) Is this interconnection likely to lead to any overall increase in electricity consumption in New South Wales or Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) In June 1997 the New South Wales and Queensland Governments agreed on a new transmission line corridor following the termination of the former Eastlink proposal by Queensland in March 1996. The two Governments are proceeding with environmental impact assessments in accordance with their own legislation. There is no require
ment for a Commonwealth environmental assessment.

(3) The interconnection as such will not lead directly to any overall increase in electricity consumption in either State. The interconnection will, however, allow Queensland to participate fully in the National Electricity Market. In conjunction with the ongoing reform of the electricity supply industries in New South Wales and Queensland, the lower electricity prices expected from the resulting greater efficiency and industry competitiveness should stimulate business activity in those industries where electricity is a major input. Consequently, electricity demand would rise commensurate with this increased economic activity.
